The recreational lagoon "Tantaycocha" is an artificial lagoon located in the park of legends, this place is ideal for boat rides and driving pedal boats, in the center there are two islands, it also has a tunnel in which you can appreciate the image of one of the 7 wonders of the modern world "Machu Picchu", it is highly recommended if you like to take walks in lagoons, it also has some dolphin sculptures in the center, for soles per person you can take a boat ride and for 9 soles you can drive a pedal boat for two people.

I visited this cafe with a friend on a weekday afternoon and we had our choice of tables. Service was friendly and attentive.

I opted for a cappuccino and avocado toast, and shared the hummus with a friend since it was supposed to be really good. Sadly, there was very little flavor to any of the food and I had to reach for the salt grinder, which I never do.

There’s another spot just down the road that serves one of the best tostada con plata dishes I’ve had in Lima. Next time, we will head there instead since the conversation was the best part of this outing.

Every place where mass is held is equally important.

The atmosphere is peaceful. It has welcoming facilities and the place is well maintained. The church is medium-sized and looks tidy. Everything is fine: the atmosphere, the well-maintained infrastructure, the priest's homily in simple and understandable language, the prayers to the Blessed Virgin Mary and Saint Joseph at the end of Mass, etc.

What really caught my attention was the church choir: it is very festive, using various musical instruments, including the charango, bass drum, shaker, tambourine, guitar, etc. The choirs (with various singers) also draw attention with their harmonies and some changes in the rhythms and cadences of the songs, making them even more joyful compared to those I've heard in other churches.

For a moment, I thought I was at a celebration in a Protestant church.

I am also surprised that at the time of the Eucharist, they begin to play songs with very cheerful melodies when receiving Jesus is a solemn and reflective moment. There is joy in receiving Christ, of course, but after receiving the body of Jesus, the person goes to their seat and says a prayer and communicates with Jesus God, praying and giving thanks for the gift received... but I feel that the songs are too distracting. In other parishes, they play "Fisher of Men" and similar songs, which seem more appropriate to me.

It would be nice to return to the times of solemnity and respect for the sacrifice that is the Mass, because as we know, in the Mass the sacrifice of the cross is made present and is an offering to God. We should be aware of this fact and avoid distractions. Regarding musical instruments, Pope Pius X recommended the use of the organ, but there are many recommendations that are no longer heeded, giving way to modern customs. As I heard recently: the Church should not adapt (modernize) to the times, but rather the opposite.
It's a business deal between the priest and the people who attend. It's not religious at all; it's not a place of faith, it's a place of lust and idleness. I hope this comment helps someone.

It's a beautiful church, with a special space for people with small children. This space provides some noise isolation for other attendees and allows parents with young children to hear the Mass better, as they don't have to leave the church to calm their children (they can have them walk around in this space, and even entertain themselves with a toy). I also 100% recommend Father Victor's Mass on Sundays at 6 pm, as it has a very unique style, with a touch of humor while still being spiritually uplifting.
Community life is also encouraged, and parishioners are always invited to join the various parish groups.
It's only recommended that you take precautions due to its location, as the surroundings are somewhat hectic and could be a target for theft if you're not from the area.

The newly renovated Parroquia La Virgen Milagrosa is truly a treasure in the heart of Miraflores. The moment you step inside, you are met with a sense of peace and reverence. The restored building is stunning, but it is the magnificent dome that takes your breath away which is a masterpiece of craftsmanship that draws your eyes upward in awe. Every detail speaks to the care and devotion poured into this sacred space. Whether you come to pray, reflect, or simply admire the beauty, this church is a place that uplifts the spirit and honors its deep history. A must‑see for anyone visiting Lima.

This is a beautiful church, and it is a working building, not a tourist attraction.  There were plenty of worshipers in the pews when I went for a visit.  It's beautiful inside, and it's worth stopping in when you're in the neighborhood.  The neighborhood itself also has a lot going for it.

Absolutely loved my experience at the Union Church of Lima! From the moment I walked in, I felt completely welcomed and at home. The community is warm, open, and genuinely accepting of visitors. The music was uplifting, the sermon was powerful and relevant, and the atmosphere was full of joy and connection. I’ll most definitely be returning during my time in Peru! Highly recommend to anyone looking for an English-speaking church with heart.

Back in mid 2021 I went to a Sunday service just for a short visit and to listen to the sermon. Before the service even started this random American man who had his wife and children wrapped around his arms, left his pew and approached mine which was behind him. He opened with: "Do you speak English?" which is a pretty stupid and discriminatory question to ask someone  you just met. He proceded to interrogate me and inquire about my nationality and if it was my first time visiting the church. He was invading my personal space and didn't even tell me his name. That was pretty inappropriate behavior from a regular from the church. I'd heard about discrimination against Peruvians at this place, but it'd never happened to me before. I'd been there countlesd times already even though I was not a regular anymore. I am a white Peruvian young man, but unlike some of these people I don't discriminate others on looks. Even since pastor Angus left, everything went downhill at this place.
I read some of the comments being: "If you're an English native speaker, this is the right place for you?" What about Peruvian born people? Are we not allowed into your little circle of racists and biggots even though you are the ones who are in our country and not the other way around?
Great worship and message. If English is your mother tongue, I highly recommend a visit. The focus is on Jesus Christ, not on the divisions of denominations.

Our Lady of Light Parish. A religious center in the Santa Luzmila neighborhood, in the Comas district. It is quite spacious, tidy, and clean; although it is true that some work is still needed on the floor.
If you would like a religious service, baptism, first communion, confirmation, marriage, mass, etc., you should go to the parish office, located at the entrance, but to the right of the parish. There is a room with chairs for waiting, with very friendly and prompt service.
Outside, you can see some street vendors, who are part of the exterior of the Santa Luzmila market (a few meters to the east).

Parish located on the corner of Casas and José Domingo Choquehuanca streets, across from Vallejo Park in the San Miguel district.
This place offers the same services as any other parish, but it has a small, welcoming church.

Overall, it's a good space if you're looking for a place to meditate and focus on your spirituality. Just check the opening hours, as the parish is closed to the public when there aren't Masses or events. However, the opening hours are also posted on the board.

Small parish in the San Miguel district, across from Bartolomé Herrera Park. It offers two daily Masses, confessions, and other sacraments. Simple, functional architecture with no historical or artistic value, and limited capacity.

I went for the first time on Thursday, July 18th, around lunchtime. I was passing by and was struck by the colorful place and the varied menu options. The atmosphere and food were very pleasant, but what captivated me most was the lady serving us. Despite the rush hour and the packed place, she maintained a smile, was friendly, and focused on not forgetting orders as she ran from the kitchen to the tables.
Good service, drinks taste and atmosphere 10/10.

The place is nice, but there's no air conditioning, although there is a fan that helps a bit. The staff is friendly, the beers are delicious, and the food is great! You can order board games; they have Jenga and casinos; you can definitely have a good time!

I didn't like the food; it was bland and didn't justify the price. I expected more quality and flavor for what I paid, so I don't recommend this place. The food was mediocre, and above all, the price wasn't justified by the quality. I've had better experiences at other restaurants.
A cozy and quiet place where you can have a conversation and have a good time. The food is average, but their cocktails and beers are quite nice.

The Church of San José, is a Catholic temple of republican origin. Located in the district of Jesús María. The church has been founded, in 1945. ⛪
On an architectural level, the Church of San José, is a temple that was devised, by Manuel Vidaurre Arrarás; ✝️
The height of the church is 52 meters, of which, 33 meters, are occupied by the dome that crowns the establishment; 📏
Like many catholic temples, the church floor has three naves, which differ from other structures by their Gothic tendency. 📿

This place of Catholic worship in the district of Jesus Maria in Lima features a very modern, boxy main church that is not too convenient for devotion, but is a good liturgical space. The small jewel is the old, original side chapel with its traditional stain glasses, its small side altars and images of the main Peruvian saints. The small side chapel is usually open and is dedicated to St Joseph

Traditional Church located in the Residencial San Felipe in the Jesús María district.
It holds masses every day at 4 times, which are broadcast via Facebook, as well as baptisms, marriages, confirmations and activities with the participation of the neighborhood. It is a church that is very popular with residents of the Residencial, as well as Japanese descendants due to its proximity to the Peruvian Japanese Cultural Center.
Its facilities are spacious and well ventilated, and it has a public service area, confessionals and a wake room within the premises.
From the moment you enter this Church you feel a step and closeness to the Lord.
Pleasant and spacious environment, very punctual for scheduled services.

It's hard to imagine there would be a church around here. The crowds were small, which gives the impression of a very warm and family-like atmosphere. A fond memory.

Playa Punta Roquitas is one of the most popular beaches in Lima, especially known for surfing. The waves are consistent and attract both beginners and experienced surfers, with surf schools and board rentals available right by the shore. The beach itself is rocky rather than sandy, so it’s not the best spot for sunbathing or swimming, but it makes up for it with its lively surf culture.

There’s a pedestrian path above the beach along the Malecón, offering beautiful views of the Pacific Ocean, and it’s a great place to watch the surfers. Sunset views are spectacular. Parking can be tricky during busy times, and the beach doesn’t have many facilities beyond surf-related services, so plan accordingly.

Overall, Playa Punta Roquitas is perfect if you’re into surfing or just want to enjoy the ocean atmosphere in Miraflores. For a relaxing beach day, you might prefer another spot, but for surf and energy, this place is hard to beat.

This is a great place for watching or trying out surfing or just to watch the waves crashing down.

It's just down from the Cliff parks, there are a few places with steps down.

There is an area with lots of Surf schools of you want a lesson.

My girlfriend and I were on a run along the cliff parks, the Love park then the Chinese park then down the steps and along the sea front 🌊.

It was great to see the waves crashing down, the sound of the stones rolling and the small of the Pacific.
Great place to watch the surfers or try a hand at it yourself.  There are local shops set up to rent equipment and pay for surfing sessions.  Beachs are rocky and not easy to swim in.
It's a beautiful rocky beach, popular with surfers. Early morning is the perfect time for a refreshing swim or simply relaxing and watching the waves

A very scenic view, and a nice place to stroll, sit by the beach , have a quick swim or surf.
To get to the sea by walking, there is access down a gentle meandering path on the side of a cliff that joins a walking over bridge above the motoway.
There is also a small carpark if you drive there.

Fantastic beach on Pacific coast, a heaven for beachgoers. This beach is specially loved by vave surfers. I give it to the authorities to keep the beach clean and tidy. Also security around the beach and surrounding areas is well kept. 👍😎

#LocalGuidesSurf
2 stars for the wave, not the beach or park. I hate this wave. It is a boucning, small backwash runner. People take it as a left for small distances but it always closes out. There is very little paddling to get to this spot which is why I think people surf here. It jacks up very quickly, then gets hit by the backwash coming off the beach and flattens out to nothing; the wave washes right out from under your feet. Finally, the way the Eddy from the current works, this is rumoured to be the dirtiest wave on the Costa Verde, which is a bummer.
Went here for a surfing class and got absolutely destroyed. Great waves, but go only if you know what you are doing.
Many surfers in this area . The sunset is amazing
Very  clean and safe place  to go ,there is no sand, but the water  was awesome

Playita Costa Verde is one of the more family-friendly beaches along Lima’s Costa Verde. Unlike the rockier stretches nearby, this small beach has a gentler setting and is popular with locals who come to relax, swim, or enjoy a picnic by the water. The atmosphere is calmer compared to the big surf beaches, making it a good spot if you’re looking for a casual beach day in the city.

It’s easily accessible from the coastal highway, with some basic facilities around, though parking can get tight on busy weekends. The ocean view is beautiful, and it’s a nice place to spend a couple of hours away from the hustle of Miraflores. While it may not have the fine white sand of tropical beaches, its convenience and laid-back vibe make it a worthwhile stop.

I went to Costa Verde Beach at night and loved the atmosphere. It's a peaceful place to walk, enjoy the sound of the ocean, and see the city lights reflected in the water. The area is safe and clean, and I like to come here to relax after a long day. It's a bit far from Callao, but it's always worth spending some time by the ocean and unwinding a bit.

I found space to park my motorcycle.
Nice beach. They don't allow alcohol, but I think it's better this way. You can watch the sunset and throw rocks into the sea.

It is a beach with quite a few stones, you can get to this beach from the boardwalk, specifically from the María Reiche park where it has a descent with many stairs.
I find it difficult to enter to bathe on this beach. However, some surfers enter to practice their sport.
On the other hand, this beach is more secluded than Punta Roquitas beach, which you can also go down from the boardwalk.

Playa Los Delfines is a quieter, rocky beach in Miraflores, popular with locals who enjoy jogging or walking along the Malecón rather than swimming. The beach itself isn’t sandy, so it’s not ideal for sunbathing, but it offers peaceful ocean views and a more relaxed atmosphere compared to the busier surf spots nearby.

It’s also known for the large dolphin statue that gives the beach its name, making it a nice photo stop. The surrounding cliffs and coastal paths provide beautiful views, especially at sunset. There aren’t many facilities directly on the beach, so it’s best to visit for the scenery, a walk, or some quiet time by the water.
Pebble beach with long Pacific waves. Accessible through a pedestrian bridge across the highway. Nice ocean feeling. Do recommend checking.
Nice waves

It's rocky and the water is relatively cold. There are no restaurants or food nearby for a snack or a meal. I only recommend it for a visit, to appreciate the view, and to sunbathe. It's very safe and peaceful, though.
A very nice place.
That sound from the ocean on the pebble beach is so unique and soothing!
Surfing galore. Plenty of available lessons and locals in this rocky but friendly beach.

Nice beach with parking lot and public toilets available.
It's a little tricky to reach the entrance of the parking when coming by car, so be sure to drive careful.
The view from there is really beautiful
Great cannabis

The beach has a somewhat sad appearance, even though it's wide, with medium-small stones and moderate waves. It has parking, a lifeguard stand, a kiosk, soccer fields, and is good for walking. It's wide, but there aren't many people camping on the rocks. It's below Larcomar.
Cool place. Bit of a walk down, but worth the trek. Lots happening.

Enjoying a sunset with the sound of the waves hitting the pebbles on the shore is the charm of this beach, because there are any number of pebbles. We enjoyed a beautiful Lima sunset and saw several pelicans and seagulls feeding here.
There's parking and easy access. I wouldn't recommend swimming here, due to the number of pebbles, but I would recommend it for enjoying a beautiful sunset.

Very nice, this place is very quiet, it gives you a prosperity and a tranquility that is priceless. Surely right now that it is winter the beaches are very cold, but come in anyway, my friend, the beach relaxes you, it gives you good vibes and releases all those impurities. I really liked being in Lima, but remember I went in the summer, the beach was still a bit cold because I went at night, and well, it is easy to get to, there are not many people, it is pleasant.
Ótima para passar a tarde
The place is perfect to go and de-stress from the city, it is next to the road, it has parking that is usually full in summer, the caretaker actually asks you for a tip since it is public

Playa Waikiki is a well-known surf spot in Miraflores, located right below the Parque del Amor. It’s a favorite among beginner surfers thanks to its smaller, more manageable waves and the number of surf schools offering lessons and rentals right on the beach. The name gives it a fun, laid-back vibe, and the surf community here is welcoming.

Like most of Lima’s beaches, it’s rocky rather than sandy, so it’s not ideal for lounging or swimming. Instead, the charm is in its surf culture and its accessibility—it’s one of the easiest beaches to reach from central Miraflores. The Malecón above gives beautiful views of the action below, and sunsets here are especially nice.

Playa Waikiki is best if you want to learn to surf, rent a board for a few hours, or simply watch the lively scene by the water.
First time seeing a stone beach. Water is nice. I think this water is for experience swimmers because the rocks can be slippery.

A fantastic pebble beach (similar to the beaches of Batumi for example) with top-notch views of Lima's cliffs. Rich in wildlife. Great for the first contact with Lima and the Pacific Ocean. Once there you can't miss the peculiar sound when the waves backtrack.

Very busy beach over the weekend. Lots of smooth rocks the size of a fist instead of sand.  Recommend water shoes. Waves are medium to large. Good waves for surfers since they break way out before the shore.
Very nice relaxing beach!

Playa La Estrella is one of the calmer beaches along the Costa Verde, located near the Bajada Balta in Miraflores. It has a quieter atmosphere compared to the busier surf beaches like Makaha or Redondo, making it a pleasant spot for a peaceful walk or to sit by the water. The rocky shore and moderate waves mean it’s not the best for swimming or lounging, but it’s perfect if you want to enjoy ocean views without heavy crowds.

The beach takes its name from the nearby Parque La Estrella above the cliffs, which offers a great view of the coastline. It’s also a nice place to catch the sunset or simply enjoy the sound of the waves.

Playa La Estrella is best for those seeking a low-key, scenic beach stop in Miraflores rather than an active surf scene.

Yes, it is a beautiful beach,  clear water & clean sand. The water is a little to cold for me, maybe in the summer time time is best for swimming. The view of the beach through the horizon is breathtaking, blue 💙 waters 💧and calm waves. The the local beach goers seems to have a great time. So far the view of beach is incredible, I want to jump to the beach waters but I better not, I better  play it in the save way. I had a great experience here, we will come back.  Thank you  to our body guard for taking us to this location, it is so beautiful,  we love 💘 it.  Sincerely,  TONY MORA 🙏.
Loud music playing from cars at all hours of the night to as early as 5:30 am. Where is the security?
Beautiful

A medium-sized pebble beach with a steep drop-off along almost its entire short length. The waves are medium-sized, breaking almost on the shore, making swimming difficult. It's somewhat deserted, and its seawall needs work. The waters are somewhat greenish. There is a lifeguard station just below the Armendariz descent.

Playa Redondo I is a popular beach along the Costa Verde, especially loved by surfers for its strong and consistent waves. The conditions are better suited for intermediate and advanced surfers, as the waves can be powerful and challenging. Surf schools and rentals are available, but most of the action here is from more experienced riders.

Like most of Lima’s beaches, Redondo I is rocky, so it’s not designed for lounging or swimming. Instead, it’s all about surf culture and ocean views. The Malecón above the cliffs provides excellent lookout points where you can watch surfers riding the waves, and the sunsets are spectacular.

If you’re a confident surfer or just want to enjoy Lima’s surf scene at its most energetic, Playa Redondo I is a great spot to visit.
Very beautiful, and peaceful place where you can sit and lose track of time! The beach is well maintained, it's very clean. If you are visiting Lima, visiting this beach is highly recommended.

The beach has sand and stones. If you want to go in the sea, you have to wear aquashoes, or there's a man who brings you seawater in a large bucket and charges you S/. It also has medical stations and several security guards.

The beach is improving its appearance. They've added sand and thatched umbrellas in one area. It's wide, with medium-sized pebbles and moderate waves. It has parking, a lifeguard station, a kiosk, soccer fields, and is good for walking. It's more crowded than its sister beach, Ronda, due to the sandy area. It's located below Larcomar.
It has a security post and you can leave your vehicle safely.

Playa La Pampilla is one of the top surfing beaches in Lima, especially for beginners and intermediate surfers. The waves are more manageable compared to Punta Roquitas, and there are plenty of surf schools and board rentals available right at the shore. The surf community here is friendly, and you’ll often see people taking lessons or practicing in groups.

The beach itself is rocky, not sandy, so it’s not the best for lounging or swimming. Still, the energy from the surfers and the beautiful views of the Pacific make it worth a visit. It’s located conveniently below Miraflores, and the Malecón above offers excellent vantage points to watch the surfers or enjoy a sunset walk.

Overall, Playa La Pampilla is ideal if you want to try surfing in Lima or simply soak in the vibrant surf culture.

#LocalGuidesSurf
Arguably the Costa Verdes best ride, and one of those rare rights in Peru. From the peak, you can ride a perfect head-high wave to the beach. A good 25 second ride. But the spot is very picky; too much tide and the wave flattens out; too much size and the current pulls you out of position. Works best all the way up to 2m on a low to mid tide.

When we arrived, the sun wasn't very bright and it was cloudy, chilly, and breezy. Then the sun began to come out, and the area became more enjoyable. Many parts of the entire coastal path aren't maintained and are somewhat neglected—the benches, the lanterns, even the bicycle and pedestrian bridge. Keeping these details in mind, it's still beautiful to walk near the beach.
Beach with small stones, you can rest peacefully, few people. Waves a little strong, wear shoes because it is a little painful to walk on the pebbles

A beach with small stones in the north and large ones in the south. You can even lay out your towel or swim in the pool. It has medium to large waves with strong retreat. There are lifeguards, and swimming is a bit rough. There are surfers in the background. Cars park along the waterfront.

Playa Makaha is one of the most iconic surfing beaches in Lima and a must-visit for anyone wanting to catch waves along the Costa Verde. Known for its consistent surf, it attracts both beginners and seasoned surfers. Several surf schools and board rental shops operate right at the beach, making it one of the easiest spots to learn or practice.

The beach is rocky, like most in Lima, so it’s not ideal for sunbathing, but the lively surf culture more than makes up for it. The view of the cliffs and the Malecón above adds to the atmosphere, and it’s also a great place to simply watch surfers in action if you’re not hitting the water yourself.

Overall, Playa Makaha is best for surfing and soaking up Lima’s coastal energy—one of the top choices for water sports in Miraflores.

I took a surf lesson for the fist time. They provided me a wetsuit, shoes and a surf board. It was twenty minutes of basic skills on site and then one hour in water. The temperature was 18'C and the water was a little bit cold. It was definitely fun.
Nice surfing beach, but there are sea urchins. Make sure you wear water shoes and try not to step on the rocks.

Great for beginner surfers. The beach is all rocks, not sand, so wear sandals. The locals are nice, ans surf lessons are reasonably priced. My girlfriend amd I went surfing for the first time and we both got up on the surfboard. She didn't even know how to swim. There's ussually a few locals with GoPros who will sell you pictures and videos of you surfing. Great experience!
Playa Makaha or Macaca hmmm. Nice from afar but once up close the beach smells weird and the muscles are spoiling on the rocks and flys everywhere. If you don't mind this then it's ok.
Lugar calmo, seguro e incrível para ver o por do sol.

Redondo Beach in Miraflores is a popular spot for surfers and vacationers. In the summer, the heat and sun are intense, so bring sunscreen. I tried a delicious raspadilla (or shaved ice) with delicious flavors at a good price (there was a special offer for two). A great place to visit any day of the week.
It's a very pretty place. It has a good view.
Spacious and clean. Recommended for children.
Incredible
Can't go to Lima and Miraflores if you are going to miss this.Absolutely magnificent!
Amazingly beautiful views 😍 and you can walk to anything you need, whether you're looking for a quick bite, fine dining, groceries, dessert, entertainment, etc
Beautiful views and walk. Definitely a great stop when in town and get a feel of the city

I love this area. There is so much to do! So much and you could really spend all day here just sitting, people watching and more. I have also ran here too! If you are looking for a free activity please visit here.
Nice view
Beautiful view for sunset and for walking along the beach 🏖️.

The best beach on the entire Costa Verde, it has waves less than a meter high and is quite calm.

One of the best views of the Pacific Ocean from Lima, before that bridge existed.

Excellent, without words.

Playa Makaha is a beautiful beach located in the Miraflores district of Lima, Peru. It's known for its scenic coastline and is a popular destination for beachgoers and surfers. The beach offers a relaxed atmosphere, making it a great place to enjoy the sun, sand, and surf.

Beach is filled with boulders, so not good to wade in shallow waters. Surfing though is fun. Rent gear, surf board and instructor for cheap!

There is no pedestrian access. They should add showers to remove the salt, changing rooms, and public restrooms. The beach is rocky; take precautions; sun exposure is direct, as there are no parasol rentals. If you are traveling with children, it is advisable to bring your own vehicle or pay for a taxi, as the road to Larco Avenue is steep and has many stairs.

You can go downstairs for snacks or a drink; it's super quiet.
There are public restrooms.
Surf beach, there are various surf schools and some restaurants or food shops
I loved this place because it is beautiful and where you can practice surfing and there are good teachers who teach you if you are one of those people who like extreme sports I recommend it.

Playa Villa beach is beautiful. It is located in the region of Lima, Peru and belongs to the district of Chorrillos. The surrounding area is bustling with activity and activities. The view itself is magnificent.
Super chill
Morning time view
Relax 😎🌊🌊🌞
Nice place

Sandy beach, safe to swim. Can rent 2 chairs & umbrella for 30 soles, totally worth it. Worth a taxi ride if you want to swim at the beach. There are some free showers near a fenced in soccer field. Bathrooms cost 1 sole, bring your own toilet paper.
Nice beach with different activities to do other than just beach sitting, even in the Peruvian winter!
You get molested by approx. 25 vendors per hour. Also crowded, noisy and full with trash. At least the sand is nice. And during weekdays you might have more peace.

This beach is amazing we had some of the best times jumping the waves. The waves were nearly 15 feet high and perfect for surfing there were many people here but it felt very private if you rent an umbrella for a very small amount of soles you can have your own two chairs and you get beer with it. I would totally come back to this beach someday I hope to be able to return and tour the city more than I got to in the two weeks I was just there. I definitely plan on returning to Surf this beach again.
A nice beach that was not too crowded when I went. I wouldn’t have high expectations but does everything a good beach has

Nice little cozy beach, outside of the crowded area of Barranco or Miraflores! You have to pay few soles to rent a chair, but it worth it if you plan to stay for a little while at the beach! Also different sellers are walking around but are not so annoying. Good place to swim, altought the waves were pretty rough the day we went!

🏖️ Playa Herradura is much quieter beach than massive Playa Agua Dulce at Barranco which gives bit of peace of mind and room to enjoy more. 🏊👙🐬⛱️

Beach is sandy, however, closer to shore it's rocky, so be careful when walking on them, it may not be stable.

Another best part is having a vista point, Espigon Salto Del Fraile, just 10min north of the beach where you can enjoy beautiful sunset 🌅
Great view of the beach!
The place is abandoned...like a ghost town
Nice beach with a view of the mountain cliffs. Rocky shore but sandy close to the water
Nice small beach next to the fishermen pier in Chorrillos, Peru.
One of the sandy beaches! Lovely restaurants with the most fresh and delicious fish.

review_text: Very locals

Great for sports, the sea is very calm. You can find many paddle tennis shops. I went on a Monday and the place was packed, so I can't even imagine what it's like on a weekend. At night, many people stay around, making bonfires or drinking.

A small, sandy beach, about 100 meters wide, located between the Regatas Club and the Chorrillos fishing pier. Its waters are very calm, ideal for swimming, paddleboarding, and kayaking. **Update May 25: The beach has been renovated by the municipality. There is no longer vehicle access, but pedestrian access is available through the fishing terminal. The terminal is open and vehicles can enter, but the access is under construction. Paddleboard and kayak rentals are no longer available. The restaurants have been removed. Group boat tours are available from the pier. Fishing is allowed from the pier, and fishing tackle vendors are available.

The beach is fair to difficult to access from the green coast. It is better to go in a group, never alone. There are a couple of stalls to buy food and drinks. I do not recommend going into the water, the waves break very hard on the shore and although it may not seem like it, it is very dangerous, as a result I have a fracture in my foot and I will be on crutches for a month. Very nice views, but excessively dangerous beach.

Difficult to access, but a beautiful spot. No security personnel were seen around, but if you go with friends during the day, it shouldn't be a problem. Coarse sand, dunes, beautiful views, and a beautiful sunset.
A very nice beach, quite pleasant to spend time with the whole family, it has plenty of security and a place to park your cars.

A beach with strong waves. Ideal for a morning jog. Opposite it is a promenade with areas for outdoor sports, a synthetic running track, and a bike path. Toward the end, rock formations give it an attractive atmosphere. It's recommended to go in a group, as it's safe there.
Calm water and rather clean beach during weekdays. In summer it gets really crowded but nice and relaxed

A very nice place. The municipality organizes sports activities. It's recommended to go in the mornings rather than in the afternoons. Although there aren't many restaurants nearby, the only one is the seafood restaurant next door. If you want to eat something else, you have to walk up several blocks to barely find a restaurant. And at the main entrance, on the left side as you enter, there's a very, very neglected area.

I can't understand anyone who likes the beach.  Firstly, right on the street, crowded and extremely loud. Apparently everyone wants to be the best DJ and turns up the boombox, regardless of whether anyone wants to hear it or not. Umbrella costs 30 soles per day. Some beach vendor is shouting every minute. So you can't relax there.

One of Peru's most beautiful popular beaches. It's part of the Costa Verde circuit, and I recommend visiting Monday through Friday, starting at 4 p.m., as it's very crowded on Saturdays and Sundays. Photo: @miguelmejiacastro
Really cold water on a cloudy day. Hard to access because of stairways. Needs more upkeep

This beach is private...it is located behind the Morro, and can be reached via the Spider Pass, which is reached by walking along the rugged coast from the Horseshoe, bordering the cliffs of the Morro...on this beach there are vestiges of a tower from the time of the war between Chile and Peru...

The route to La Chira via La Herradura beach is adventurous and of medium risk. The beach itself is pretty, clean, the sea is rough. I haven't seen any swimmers. It doesn't have any services and the AAHH population is at the back on the hill. I don't know how safe it is.
An adventure to get to this beach, I definitely had a lot of fun
I went for a run on this beach and spent a pleasant moment of peace and tranquility. The sound of the beautiful sea and the absence of people allows it to be clean.
Very nice place, with a beautiful view and nice restaurants. Bring a coat as it is cold at night.
Good place to go jogging! Or biking or walking....u name it! Open space, nice view close to the sea.

A few details missing, but it's wide and long, for a good walk or jogging.

Playa Barlovento is one of many on the stretch of Pan Americana heading south from Lima. It's a nice beach, but with a dangerous, hollow shore-break. Reasonably maintained by the municipality, but as soon as you walk away from the controlled area, there is tons of garbage and dead animals. The municipality of #Chorillos needs to do a much better job of managing and maintaining this precious resource; more trash cans, more bathrooms and ENFORCING of bylaws!
Ok
Very nice, few people and very quiet, excellent for spending a relaxing afternoon

This beach spot is incredibly beautiful. Its wide coastline, accompanied by an equally large boardwalk, catches your eye as soon as you look at it. Nature is at its most splendid. Seabirds reflect the richness of its waters. The sound of the waves helps relax the mind. However, it's worth noting that it's not a place for wading into the water too much because it's choppy. Children and the elderly are not allowed on the shore. There are no restrooms or showers to rinse off the salt water. As a place for contemplation and relaxation, it has a high recommendation from me.
very good big waves

Great setting fine views. Lovely to take a walk on the cliff top road and pavement. well maintained gardens and parks. Shame the sea front/ promenade is physically cut off by the highway with few crossing points though.

Not a beach to spend the day only recommended for surfing. It is a very dirty beach, with a lot of people and pets. We go only for the surfing classes. If you go for surfing then 5 stars!!

Was fine. Checked the box for going to the beach in Lima. Beach had sand, which was good because beaches just up the road were only rocks. It also has umbrellas and chairs to rent, which is also nice since other beaches didn’t look to have that available. We got one umbrella and four chairs for 30 soles, probably could have negotiated lower sine the beach wasn’t busy at 10am. It was fairly clean, only a little bit of junk that washed ashore or was left behind. There were “drifter” people packing up their camp and washing themselves in the water when we arrived. They didn’t make a show of it so it wasn’t a huge deal. There were portable toilets that were locked, we didn’t use them but I’m assuming we would have had to pay someone to open it for us. All in all, it was just fine. Definitely been to better beaches in the world but deemed good for Lima.
Amazing spot for taking pictures during the winter time. I wouldn’t try doing that in the summer though. Lots of ppl on the beach and no public bathrooms
Stunning. Recommended renting bikes and cycling the seaside route. Fabulous.

During our visit to Playa Barrancos, we took the opportunity to walk along the malecón all the way back to our hotel. The path is quite suitable for a leisurely stroll, though it’s worth noting that some parts of the walkway could benefit from better maintenance and cleaning.

Despite this, sitting by the shore to watch the sunset proved to be a memorable experience. The view of surfers riding the waves as the sun dipped below the horizon was truly captivating. While Playa Barrancos may not be the cleanest beach, it certainly has its moments of beauty, especially during the evening. It’s a great spot for those looking to relax and enjoy some natural coastal charm.
Nice spot with lots of visitors on the weekend to sit on the rocks and look at the ocean.
Very tranquil, great place to relax and unwind
Nice
The place is simply beautiful. The day I went, there was a lot of seaweed on the shore. Is it always like this?

Nice, typical west coast beach that's very rocky. We had a good time .Always keep an eye on your car because there thieves that will break into your car in less 15 min- it happen to me. Don't leave anything in the view of the window.
So expensive rent umbrellas and chairs. So Many  street foods. The better the beach and white  sand.

Be careful with these people, they offer you one price when you go to pay the jack up the price. Bad business practice!!

Really nice place to relax, listen to the waves crash against the rocks, and watch the surfers. Unfortunately there’s garbage thrown carelessly around the beach - other than that, it’s a great location.

Big round rocks and big waves crushing in.  not for small kids. A bit less hectic and som fishermen at the "pier". Easy parking access. Walkable from Barranco. Maybe we was super lucky but 5.march we saw lots of seaturtles from the beach! Awsome.

There are a variety of restaurants along the Costa Verde, near Barranco. They're closed during the quarantine period, but you can walk around.

This place is charming in summer, its sunsets are a living art. Warm colors in temperate climate.

This beautiful sandy beach of quiet waters had improved with time. Now it looks more organized and neat. It's the favorite place for many.

If you go early enough you can find parking. There is a parking fee regardless of whether you find a place or not. The beach is clean and it has beach volley-ball courts. Plenty of restaurants and places to rent chairs.

He founded Mamacona has several rooms, the one shown is a meeting center.
It has green spaces for events and a dance section. It also has bathrooms and other spaces.

The San Pedro boardwalk has a large number of restaurants specializing in seafood and a la carte dishes. Most of them have taken over the parking lot by placing chairs or other materials along the waterfront to prevent parking if you don't eat there. If you're just coming to enjoy the sea, keep in mind that, to avoid ruining your day, look for a place that charges a service fee. The service and preparation of the dishes are average, depending on your tastes.

From the moment you arrive at San Pedro Beach, you're enveloped by a sense of tranquility and natural beauty that only this place can offer. It's easily accessible and surrounded by a picturesque coastal landscape that invites you to disconnect from your routine and immerse yourself in a relaxing atmosphere.

The soft, warm sand is perfect for walking barefoot while enjoying the sun and the sea breeze. The crystal-clear water has a turquoise hue that looks like something out of a postcard, ideal for swimming or simply relaxing on the shore while listening to the sound of the waves.

In addition, the gastronomic offering near the beach is a true delight. Local restaurants offer a variety of fresh seafood prepared with traditional recipes, ranging from exquisite ceviches to parihuelas that revive the soul. All accompanied by warm service that makes you feel right at home.

San Pedro is not only perfect for sea lovers, but also for those looking for a serene place to share with family or friends. The sunset views are simply magical and offer an unforgettable moment you'll want to capture in a photo.

I recommend San Pedro Beach as an excellent option for a family getaway.

Small garden in honor of Chinese immigrants to Peru. A small Pagoda is in its center, surrounded by a shallow koi pond. Buddha statues here and there, and a couple plastic pandas which you can take pictures with. Oriental music plays from a speaker.

The whole thing struck me as in-authentic and a poor representation of a Chinese garden. The pond is overflowing with fish and filthy, hasn't been cleaned for ages. I pity the fish in there.

Good walk to take after a nice meal to enjoy the view, from the malecon (shore) and the breeze of the sea, it gets crowded in the evenings so go early in the afternoon so can get nice pictures of the sunset and the park, there's an area for kids to play in the upper level. Good location for a picnic with the family, just keep in mind the areas where the Chinese statues are is kind of small.

It’s was built to recognize Chinese emigres, but it probably the most poorly designed park in the Malecon. There’s nothing Chinese about it👎👎👎.

The focal point is a pergola that is a pseudo-pagoda👎👎👎…looks pretty from a distance but not quite the Buddhist nor Taoist  design.

The so-called garden is even worst. There’s a very shallow pond, more like a hand washing pool, that is so overcrowded with Koi👎. The poor creatures must be boiling in it under the heat of the equatorial sun. Over this pond a “bridge”, more like 3- foot plank, that is made of hollow plastic resin.

Then there the small buddhas, plastic pandas and other trinkets👎👎👎👎👎… it is like a child’s toy land.

From the pavement above it, is a place to watch the sunset as is any other spot on the Malecon.
Small Chinese park with panda statues, a pagoda and walking paths. Seems quite popular with the locals. Nice views from here

This was a delightful surprise while walking on the beachfront boardwalk in Miraflores. There were two wedding photographers working with clients while I was here, and it is a beautiful site for it. The statuary, pond, and plants make this a sanctuary worthy of reverence. Plus there are vast views of the ocean. Check out this gem of you are in the area.

Considering the size of Lima there is remarkably little to do for kids. This park is one of the few fun things. It's quite small. You're done in two hours. But it's a fun distraction for kids aged below 10 years old.

Pretty fun experience for kids, my 6 year old enjoyed himself for about 3 hours here. There is an aquarium, some tunnels with dinosaur animatronics, an Africa themed train ride , an earthquake simulator... Additionally, they have some paid rides and jumpy games not included in the 15 soles entrance. It is no Disney world, but it's something to do with kids in Lima.
Nice place to bring your kids for a reasonable price.
Good place enjoyed alot specially for kids it's great fun
It is small but full of fun. Disappointing they charge extra to use the playground. But that is Peru
Nice Park to walk, exercise and be with friends and family
Went hiking here for like 22 miles
Super

It's a pretty little park that, despite its size, has two benches, a bike path on the La Marina Avenue side, a tourist information center, a Preventive Health Center, a security guard booth, a guard, and bicycle parking.
Don't be confused, the phone number on the Preventive Health Center sign is for the security guard, not the center.
It also has a monument in honor of John XXIII. It's an example for the other parks in the area to follow.

A beautiful park with well-maintained green areas and trees. It's open to the public; anyone can come and sit. Ideal for those who want to take photos in a green setting. It's close to main avenues like the marina and Faucet. Pets are welcome; many come here. The only caveat is that the benches don't have shade. So, in the middle of summer or on a sunny day, you can't take shelter on the benches, and only in the central section.

The park is very well lit and organized. There are trash cans around the entire perimeter and benches for resting only in the central area. It's a good place to enjoy a moment of reading or taking a break from work.

The outing would have been great if a man had been careful to put his dog on a leash or be aware that other people were also arriving at the park to prevent his pet from jumping on mine. Only when I reacted, looking for the owner, did he deign to put down his cell phone to tell me: "Oh, but he only jumps to sniff."

Good place.. Its benches are very high.. A strange thing.. And that's even though I'm not short (1.75) average lighting.. And if you want to know.. If people park their cars in the park. And there's enough space
It's very pretty and well maintained.

There are 2 modalities, pay 60 to play all the games (only 1 time) or pay 100 and they give you 10 tickets, that is, if you are accompanied you play in 5 modules per person (there are 8 modules).
The games are of a medium level and are not demanding except for the arena, which is high.

The location is easy to get to in the middle of the Panamericana before the Campo Fe cemetery.
It is recommended to wear light clothing

Recommended... there were some things to improve, but mainly it was cool and safe hahahaha which is what worried me the most, recommended to go with someone or in person

They've added rides for the little ones, and they've removed some of the more extreme rides. I suppose to avoid accidents. Of all the rides, I only went on three, which I thought were the most worthwhile: Tagada, Blackjack (I think that's what it was called), and the one at the back where you spin while standing.
Each adult ride costs 10 S/.
The kids' rides are 8 S/.
The magic bracelet is 60 S/. And it lets you enter any ride as many times as you want.

They even have portable toilets free of charge.

Every game was fun, and the wait to buy tickets and get in was quick. The games change, though. I remember there were others before, but they were still fun. Everything was very clean. Bring your kids 😄❤️👋🏾

A fun place to relax for a while. The games and prizes are good, although you need a large number of tickets to win good prizes.
I recommend visiting this place.
Most of the games are ticketed, but there are few rides for kids. Before attending FunKids, you must fill out a form with your information.
The roulette wheels (Big Bass Wheel, Monster Jackpot, etc.) seem to be programmed to always or almost always give out 15 tickets. Aside from that, many machines didn't give out any tickets at all.
Very good for children. Lots of games.

This place is perfect for hosting children's parties. They have well-organized and clean play areas, which is great for kids. Plus, safety is a priority here, which made me feel at ease while the little ones enjoyed themselves. I highly recommend this trampoline park for any special occasion!

We celebrated my son's birthday here, and it was phenomenal! The trampoline park has an amazing energy, and the kids had a blast jumping everywhere. Plus, the staff was very attentive and helped us run the party smoothly. We'll definitely be back next year!

When we were looking for a place to celebrate my daughter's birthday, we wanted something that was safe but also fun. This trampoline park met all our expectations. The kids had a blast, and we were able to enjoy the party without any worries.

Hosting my son's birthday party here was an excellent choice. The trampoline park team took care of everything, from decorations to food, allowing me to relax and enjoy the day with my family. Thank you for making this day so special!

My daughter loves all the games, every time she goes, she asks me for them and since everything is so clean and cared for with great taste, it makes me want to take her on the games that she really likes.
Nice and spacious place although it lacks a variety of games.

The space is spacious, clean, and safe enough for children. It's located across from the Real Plaza VMT food court.
There are a variety of fun games for children and teens, but there's no option for parents, as they have to wait, so that would be a good alternative.
Very fun entertainment place for adults and children

This is one of my favorite places. It is a beautiful park and is well-maintained. Certain times of the day/evening are busier, and there are usually a lot of wedding and quinceanera photographers. It's fun to watch though -- a lot of beautiful gowns.

Parque de la Felicidad was designed to cover and protect Surco River that crosses that area. It has a biophysical water treatment plant, that includes the use of water hyacinth to extract heavy metals that are potentially present in Surco River water. Good place for an academic visit with students. It is under the administration of San Borja City Hall (Municipalidad de San Borja).
Look, I know it's a popular spot to take photos but it was absolutely trashed. The sidewalks were nasty and the "lake" is gross, it's literally green.
Lovely park with fountains, very well kept gardens and children’s climbing frames
Really beautiful park, clean and well maintained. However, a lot of people go there to take professional pictures for weddings and ceremonies that make it a little bit crowded

Kallpa Wasi (Energy house, from Quechua language) is a perfect place to educate students about renewable sources of energy (e.g photovoltaic and biogas), as well as biomass transformation (e.g. compost from horse, guinea pig, and rabbit manure and vermicompost from earthworms). Good choice for an academic visit. It is under the administration of San Borja City Hall (Municipalidad de San Borja).

The last time I went was 11 long years ago, and all I wanted to do was see the animals, go to the wave pool, and ride the rides, since it was the Granja Villa in the northern cone. It was a place that marked the most fun moments of my childhood, which I still fondly remember. There's no information about the park's theme change in any area; I can only look at photos on Maps. Not even the AI ​​could help me. I haven't visited Yaku Park, mind you, but I can glean from the reviews. I hope to have updated information from the staff or someone who has been there recently about the existence of rides inside and the wave pool. I hope you'll be able to read this. I need to comfort my inner child after learning that the only remaining Granja Villa is on the other side of this one.

Um lugar ótimo para ir um só dia e aproveitar de tudo. Tem alguns animais de fazenda, brinquedos de parque de diversão ( barca, carro de bate bate... ) Brinquedos para crianças e adultos... Restaurante, pequenos quiosques que vendem água , lanches e sorvete.   E possui uma área muito boa de piscinas. Também com uma loja que vende roupa de banho ( não é barata) , protetor solar...
O que eu não gostei é que eles tem muitas exigências para a área das piscinas e vários guardas ficam abordando as pessoas e constrangendo com um mínimo detalhe em sua roupa que não los pareca bem. As roupas tem que ser especificamente de lycra  impermeável se não não pode entrar. Sua solução será comprar aí uma roupa de banho caro.
E não se pode entrar com nenhum tipo de alimento na bolsa, somente água.
Também possui estacionamento e muitos táxis e moto-taxis na entrada.
Ok

Extraordinary place, very spacious and fun.
Super friendly staff. The request is always submitted

I'll start with the quality, which has dropped significantly this year. The pools are obviously poorly maintained. The slides are dirty and dusty on the outside, and the lack of paint in areas where the wear and tear on the bottom of the pool is noticeable, making it feel greasy. The floor/ground has some areas where something sticks out (it seems to be part of the material that ends in points), so if you brush your foot or knees against it, you can easily come out with scrapes and open wounds.

You can find dirty things in the pool, which is very unpleasant. We found a strip of underwear floating, and it stayed there for a while.

So, the last time I went, about two weeks ago, everyone in my family broke out in hives and itchy skin. We stopped eating because everyone ate something different. Maybe that's why there was a live report at the beginning of the year that I wasn't fit for use. I don't know what happened, but everything was fine. But oh well.

On the other hand, in other years the staff was more aware of everything, both the lifeguards and others.

The only clean thing I found was the restrooms at the beginning, and that's because by the end it was dirty due to the demand of people.

I hope they can improve by 2026.

A kid-friendly place, clean and tidy. They don't have their own garage, but you can park nearby. There are lifeguards on staff throughout the area. However, the music is too loud; you're going there for family time, not a nightclub. The food is expensive and not very good; a cookie costs 5 soles, a bottle of water 5 soles, high prices not in keeping with the place. They're very strict about bringing things into the venue, obviously aiming to buy everything inside. Admission is 40 soles for children and adults. They have a wide variety of slides for children, which is very good, even the pool is approximately 1.2 meters deep for most of the space. I would return just to bring children; adults are overrated.

Nice, small place, especially for children, as it only has two or three pools, and the main one doesn't exceed 80 cm or 1 meter at most. But it's in good condition and not too crowded during the week. Admission is 35 soles from Monday to Friday. There's no parking; you must leave your car outside.
Large very nicely maintained park with the usual amenities, Children's play zone, workout area, religious shrine, etc...lots of friendly  people walking their dogs until midnight

It’s our neighborhood park and had been closed for over a year for renovations. It reopened in December of 2020 and is absolutely an oasis in the Lima concrete jungle. It’s great for families to have a nice walk. Relax and enjoy the plentiful and very distanced park benches. Due to covid restrictions the exercise equipment is not allowed to be used. There is a Serenazgo station in the middle of the park and it is extremely safe. It’s a great place to workout, run, do yoga or just sit and people watch. Masks are mandatory as of this review(02/2021).
Beautiful big park with tall trees and home of eagles. A small cement gathering to sit and read or just enjoy. Guarded fairly.

Until September 2019, this park was a spectacular place where people could play sports, walk their pets, and children could play, and where incredible nature, trees, flowers, and grass grew. Now, thanks to the improvisation of a municipal authority, it's all destroyed: dead grass, fallen trees, no plants, and no people to enjoy it. It should have been ready, as the mayor of Pueblo Libre attempted to do in December 2019, but it's abandoned to its fate. Photos are attached.
Nice park, the green areas are clean, there's a security booth in the park itself, the games are new; just that due to protocols they can't be played yet, for everything else it's a nice place.
Nice, it has varied games for small children, primary children and adolescents 💃🤽
full diversion !

A wonderful experience for both adults and children. I suggest keeping an eye on the time you have left, as it flies by.

Very enjoyable, especially for my nephews, who had fun with these Inflata Park games. They want to come back for more. They loved it. I highly recommend it. It costs S/. 25 if you're a Surcano resident and S/. 50 for others.
AWFUL!! Disorganized, messy... and the bathrooms are closed to children. It's awful that they're located deep in the park and don't have bathrooms. Don't come here.

A great place to spend a fun afternoon with your friends. Admission varies depending on how long you'll be on the inflatable circuit. It offers a variety of games, courses, challenges, and more. A great way to spend a fun afternoon with friends.

A lovely place to visit with kids, there is a free playground, a kid´s bathroom, various food, drink and snack options, an electric train ride possibility, a lagoon wiht paddle boats and an arc from which you have a great view over the surroundings.

Such a fun place to take kids! It’s about 30
minutes from San Isidro neighborhood but well worth it. From the adorable train ride, the lake boats and ducks, and the amazing bouncy fun zone that is massive, there is so much to do here for almost 3 hours. It’s sprawling and well landscaped, it’s truly a nice place to visit with lots to do. It feels non-touristy and more of a local gem.

This place is not that big. But big enough to pass a good time. Have a theatre, a small train going around , a beautiful arch that is Spanish ottoman architecture, some beautiful fountains, lots  of different birds, a museum, benches, coffee shops and  entertainment for  kids, is free entrance, I went for  a walk with my father like doing some shopping and we were lost  at this wonderful place. Highly recommend to spend some time in here.

We had a wonderful day. Perfect place to spend the day with kids in Lima. We went as a family group ages from 2-17 kids/teens and 42-74 adults. Everyone had a great time with games, rides, the pools, and waterslides. We also enjoyed visiting the farm animals. We spend >6h and didn't see everything (mostly because we spend a lot of time in the waterpark).

Such a cute place to visit with the kiddos, a lot of restrictions around pools unlike waterparks in other countries, e.g no walking with shoes or must have bathing suits on before walking inside pool area and no using hot tub after 4pm on weekdays, but putting those aside definetely makes it worth going with the kids for a nice outing.

It's really comprehensive. They also sell food and have a Food&Plus Restaurant with grilled chicken and a vegan option. Action park of more than 20,000 m2 that offer game packages whose prices vary according to the combinations chosen. Important information is that they present games aimed at children from 2 to 7 years old, adolescents from 8 to 12 and those over 12.

The newly renovated Parroquia La Virgen Milagrosa is truly a treasure in the heart of Miraflores. The moment you step inside, you are met with a sense of peace and reverence. The restored building is stunning, but it is the magnificent dome that takes your breath away which is a masterpiece of craftsmanship that draws your eyes upward in awe. Every detail speaks to the care and devotion poured into this sacred space. Whether you come to pray, reflect, or simply admire the beauty, this church is a place that uplifts the spirit and honors its deep history. A must‑see for anyone visiting Lima.

This is a beautiful church, and it is a working building, not a tourist attraction.  There were plenty of worshipers in the pews when I went for a visit.  It's beautiful inside, and it's worth stopping in when you're in the neighborhood.  The neighborhood itself also has a lot going for it.
Beautiful church next to the cat park. Very impressive construction with great atmosphere inside. God bless you.

Worth a visit. Beautiful church. One of the major church within Miraflores area. Nice location. Located between two beautiful park. Has an underground parking in front  within the park. Lots of shopping and dinning options nearby. Within a hip area.

The Church of San José in Tambo Viejo (Cieneguilla) was built on the site of the San Martín Chapel in Tambo Viejo, which collapsed. The new church we see today was built in 2007, thanks to the support of the Franciscan missionaries, the Archbishopric, and the parishioners of Cieneguilla.
Before its neo-colonial style, the San José Church was only a small chapel, but with all the effort and care dedicated to it, it has become a very representative parish for everyone. The façade shows a central section with two towers at each end, each with bells. At the top, on the pediment, you can see the images of Saint Joseph, Saint Rose of Lima, and Saint Martín de Porres.
Beautiful church with 2 towers, the San José Church. In the middle of Cieneguilla's main square

Update 2024: A beautiful symbolic church in Lince. Perhaps they should allow a 5 p.m. Mass schedule since the elderly, with the cold weather, often can't go out at 6 or 7 p.m. I've also heard calls for longer confession times, which I agree with. The Sacrament of Reconciliation is necessary.
Please fix the speakers a bit, as the homily is often hard to understand, and since the church is large, there's a lot of echo and reverberation.

Update 2019:
An iconic spot in the Lince district. Located across from Pedro Ruiz Gallo Park, attendees can park their cars because there are well-marked parking spaces. The church is beautiful without being ostentatious. It has a tower with a clock that years ago could be seen from almost the entire district. Now, with the indiscriminate proliferation of buildings, this is no longer possible.

Since 1969, the Santa Catalina de Siena Parish has provided religious and community services to the Buenos Aires de Villa neighborhood and surrounding areas. Founded by the Capuchin Franciscan Order, its territorial reach includes Tacalá, Vista Alegre, and San Juan de la Libertad, encompassing the chapels of San Francisco, Virgen del Carmen, and Santa Clara. It plays an important role in consolidating and promoting spirituality and cooperation, strengthening trust and solidarity among residents.

To make matters worse, the teenage girls attending the entrance were rude; they giggled upon delivering news that since I was not a member with identification, I could not visit for one session. Laughing at not being inclusive is a sign of mockery and helps maintain the image that religion is "bad" through segregation. I hope the Church reads this review in order to help raise the next generation. This is not an acceptable behavior. PS. There have been some recent renovation efforts since late 2024 and it seems it will recover some of its former glory.

It’s designated as a World Monument in 2016 😎😎😎 despite its current state of disrepair, brought about by a devastating earthquake in 1940.

The WM designation  is a tribute to its historical and local folklore significance to the origin of Lima’s Barranco Borough as a fishing village.

Originally built in the 1870s, the neo-Gothic building of the Hermitage apparently underwent several reconstructions from destructions due to the War of the Pacific in the 1880s followed by natural disasters culminating in the 1940 earthquake. It has closed to the public since 1960. Emergency repairs have been going on since then.

As it stands since its WM designation, the roof is in very bad shape. IRONICALLY, the roof especially the “barebones” of the belfry looks so eerily pleasing 😎😎😎 as though it’s the ruins of a medieval castle. It looks the home or favorite sunning spot of a flock of huge vultures (gallinazos).

—- IF EVER reconstruction re-starts perhaps the architects might just reinforce the belfry and, for aesthetics or artistic reimagination, leave the open skeleton-like structure of it??

Señor de los Milagros Parish: A historic religious site for this area of the Comas district, its origins date back to the 1960s. Its facade faces west. Located on one side of 3 de Octubre Avenue, parallel to Belaúnde Este Avenue, which leads to the upper reaches of the district.

A parish, linked to the history of Comas. Sixty years ago, when the invasions occurred in the Km. 13 sector, the first settlers, needing land to live on, took possession of this area, which they called Villa Señor de los Milagros, using their faith as their only shield and banner, the Face of the Lord. This face is venerated to this day in the Señor de los Milagros Parish of Comas, Km. 13. Many of the first settlers were arrested and imprisoned, but their persistence had the desired effect: they had land to live on. When they began to subdivide the land, they demarcated the area where the Señor de los Milagros Parish would be built. In its early years, it was managed by the Congregation of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate. The people write their history, and we are merely the actors.

Excellent place to visit and take photos and learn a little more about the history of Peru 🇵🇪🇵🇪

This place wasn't on my itinerary, but I am so glad that I went. The place does a great job of explaining the years of terrorism and violence in Peru. I had read a lot about those difficult years before and how Peru struggled with extreme violence and instability.

These exhibitions may be too graphic for some people, but I don't think it's good to hide the truth, especially when there are so many different narratives about these events. There's a section where they display the testimony of either actual victims of terrorism or close relatives of people who died during these years. I was holding back my tears.

Some people say the exhibition is biased in favor of the Peruvian government, but I didn't think that way because there are several mentions of how the Peruvian government also participated in the violence.

It is sad that the most affected were the working class and rural people. This was a tragedy.

The museum is located in a very good area, but I recommend to use a car or Uber/Cabify to get there. Entrance is free of charge and you just have to complete a simple form with your info.

The only thing I would change is that we need English translations because I think the world needs to know about this and stop pretending terrorists are social leaders.

¡TERRORISMO NUNCA MÁS!

we loved this museum! i took my parents who were university students during the peak years of terrorism and they enjoyed reflecting on the history. amazing experience, i recommend going in order to keep this historical memory alive!

LUM is one of those places that stays with you long after you leave. The building itself is striking. If you’re into understanding the story of violence, the Shining Path, the conflict years (1980-2000) and the politics, this is a must visit.

Inside, everything is in Spanish, but Google Translate come to rescue! It gives voices of those who lived through the internal conflicts. It’s moving and I thought they did a good job in being honest.

The museum explains the violence that occurred between the Shining Path libration army (Maoist socialist group that gain power in the countryside) and the military. There were many victims and you get to hear their stories. Unfortunately the English explanation was non existent. The QR codes were suppose to take you to a Google drive page with English audio but I didn’t find it there on occasion. Also, the building is built on the cliffs and being surrounded by the cliffs did not make it easy to receive any signal… what I did realized was that there were a lot about the Shining paths atrocities but there wasn’t much regarding what the military did to the citizens caught in between. I’m just a casual visitor but I could tell it just from following up on wiki that there’s more to the story.

Exhibition aside, it’s an excellent contemporary architecture that is built into the cliff side. The entrance of the building makes you descend into the depths between the building and the cliffs methodically creating the feeling of being stuck between a rock and a hard place which is what many of the victims felt. The entire museum is connected via ramps (close to being wheelchair accessible) and light penetrations from both sides (from the windows) as well as from top to bottom (from the circular sky lites and glass gaps between the slab). The roof is an open space with amazing views of the Pacific. Highly recommend it for people who enjoy history and contemporary architecture.

This museum has a great architectural profile with a rich history of the violence uprising in the country. The way you move through the museum is interesting, as you get rewarded with amazing views of the pacific coast after the exhibition(s)

Huaca Pucllana: 4000-year-old pyramid, check. Boring guide who puts you to sleep, check. If you're gonna make me walk on ancient genius pyramid, at least make the tour entertaining. Suggestion: skip the guide and hit up the Larco Museum first. Learn more over there Trust me, you'll be way more impressed when you finally get to the real education. And honestly, just read the Wikipedia page, you'll learn more.
Need tour guide and takes about one hour.

2000+ years of history packed into the center of Miraflores. A must see when visiting Lima to acquire some of the history and respect for previous civilization. The adobe architecture is incredible as millions of bricks were assembled into the pyramid that took hundreds of years to assemble. Get to see some of the agriculture and animals of Peru - guinea pigs and alpacas.

The museum offers some insight, but the real value is the guided tours that leave every 30 minutes and are offered in both English and Spanish. Cost of entry is S/ 15, about $4 (includes the tour)

This is such a fun treasure in the city! It's a quick 45-60 min tour talking about the Lima culture that predates the Inca civilization. It's not an intense hike, but closed toed shoes and pants are a good idea just because of the dust. We went on an overcast day and it was perfect, I can see it getting super hot on a sunny day, there is no shade.

We visited in the morning and it was the perfect time to go. It’s so cool to see this massive ancient site right in the middle of modern Lima and it was literally behind our hotel.

They offer tours in both English and Spanish, and it’s included in the ticket price. Yours are required to visit. Our guide did a great job explaining the history and how the structure was used by the Lima culture over 1,500 years ago. The pyramid made of adobe bricks is super impressive up close!

Huaca Pucllana is a fascinating archaeological site right in the heart of Lima. The guided tour brings the history of this ancient adobe pyramid to life, explaining its importance to the Lima culture long before the Incas. It’s incredible to see such a well-preserved piece of history surrounded by the modern city. A positive and worthwhile experience for anyone interested in Peru’s rich past. You have to have a guide with you to enter. This is part of the admission fee.
Well worth visiting with an entrance fee of 35Sol. There are 2 rooms housing historical and cultural textiles and ceramics, displayed clearly and professionally.

One of the most amazing museums I've ever been to! The plants alone in the cafe are worth a visit. Make sure to eat their carrot cake there and take notice of the museum pot exhibiting an exotic spotted cat 🐈 as a pet. The textiles obviously are out of this world and the level of fine detail will make you question if truly done by hand!

A not miss museum in Miraflores, Peru. Beautiful exhibit of first class textiles made by the pre columbian civilization of Peru. Expertly curated and presented items tell a story of the creativity and skill of ancient Peruvian civilizations

Brilliant museum about 30/35 soles I believe? Really well displayed outlining various cultures across all of peru particularly the North and southern coasts. From nazca to paracas...some incredible finds dating back to 15,000 years. Staff were very welcoming. Museum wasn't particularly busy either which surprised me as it is an incredible museum.

This museum is fabulous! It was very informative and had a fun flow to the way you walk. It was slow when I went so I had all the rooms to myself. The only criticism I have is that I wish the individual pieces had more detail/info available. Definitely worth visiting!
