Beautiful place. But they didn't have a guide temporarily, so we couldn't visit the interior of the museum. Basically, it was a walk on a park.
It was an incredible experience visiting this hotel. I am mesmerized by their hospitality and service they bring for the visitors. I would recommend this place to everyone. Thank you.
It's amazing to spend time in this museum it was a great place to visit once in a lifetime, an loved it.
It shows you the entire history of Mariscal Andrés Avelino Cáceres. Go and visit that is awesome place.
It has a good collection of one of the best animes and has won a record guiness twice. It is just a room in the third floor. It was exciting if you a fan of Saint Saiya of course.
If you are in Lima and you're a Saint Seiya follower, this place is a must to visit, very kind and nice  people will guide you, I will be back there.

Free museum dedicated to the largest saint Seiya collection in the world according to the Guinness world records.
Lots of toys and memorabilia.
Very interesting
Very legal
Historical atitude which explain many more about city
Beautiful mini things and miniatures of vehicles and buildings. Recommended for children.

A museum with scale replicas of Star Wars tanks, planes, ships, cars, and spaceships. Great fun if you're a history buff.
Upon review, I discovered there are more than 1,500 replicas in total. Each one was assembled by the museum owner, making it the largest collection in Peru, and I believe the world. I hope he continues to add more. Highly recommended.
The great work done to show us the scales of planes, tanks, and ships is simply admirable, and the Star Wars display is incredibly cool. If you're in the area, I highly recommend a stroll here.
Very nice, you find many vehicles, the vast majority are aerial but all are to scale, the place is quiet and not many people go there.
The scale samples were great and there are plenty of examples, but the layout was visually poor, and the heat was unbearable.

Wonderful museum for anyone zoology and paleontology! Not too big but packed with the remains of giants: Livyatan, Perucetus, baleen whales, extinct turtles and the giant caiman Purussaurus. Furthermore, a neat and varied ecological garden and geology hall are exhibited outside of the main building, as are two complete whale skeletons (Sperm and Bryde's whales). Had a great time!
Nice place to come and visit, really interesting, it could be great if they will put an explanation in English also 🙏🏻
Great museum with lots of information about prehistoric animals that lived in this side of the globe. Good collection of insects, fossils, stones, and taxidermy. Definitely recommend this museum!

Nice old museum... it's not modern at all, but it is part of its charm. We visited it in an hour and a half. They have a cool section on prehistoric animals and another of reptiles... very neat. The only NEGATIVE aspect is that there is no staff in the exhibition rooms so kids were screaming and parents were like if that was OK... no bueno! But other than that it was a cool visit, and cheap 10 soles, yay!!

Great Experience for a very small price of 10 S. The exhibition of animals from prehistoric area is worth it to see. There are loads of different information to learn about from. Also the minerals section was neat! Some rooms definitely need an update to fit these current times and to not look so used anymore. The outside garden is very beautiful, quiet with lots of birds and it's well maintained. Unfortunately the majority of information provided is held in Spanish only. Great place for kids with things to discover!  Keep an eye for the opening hours, it closes early.
I randomly discovered this while going to a restaurant I had mapped in advance. This was a very pleasant surprise. An extremely clean and well kept peaceful place with much to see.

The free museum is on the second floor. It opens at 10:00 am. (Both these facts were hard to find.) This place is bustling with workshops, classes, and businesses….so much, they had to build a 10-story office tower.
It was free the day we went. It was not a large museum but it was very good although, and I guess to be expected, was only in Japanese and Spanish. Still interesting for this English only person.

This cultural center represents the fusion between Peruvian and Japanese culture. This one of the best places to know more about Japanese culture in Peru. Moreover, this place is where is celebrating the Premio Nacional 5S Kaizen.

Friendly staff, but be aware that the museum and the garden closes at 6pm on the weekdays, on the weekends the museum closes very early, the only thing open until 9pm are two restaurants, the dance center, and a small art gallery, so go before 6pm

The Larco Museum in Lima is one of Peru’s finest museums and a must-visit for anyone interested in history and culture. Housed in an 18th-century colonial mansion, it features an outstanding collection of pre-Columbian art, including ceramics, textiles, metalwork, and jewelry from ancient civilizations like the Moche, Nazca, and Inca.

One of its highlights is the world-famous gallery of erotic pottery, which is both fascinating and unique. The museum also offers beautifully curated exhibits with clear explanations in multiple languages, making it easy to understand Peru’s rich cultural heritage. The gardens and café add to the experience, creating a relaxing atmosphere after exploring the galleries.

Perfect for culture lovers, history buffs, and anyone wanting a deeper understanding of Peru before (or after) visiting its archaeological sites.

This museum isn't very big but it has amazing pieces. I would really recommend a guided tour which is offered at an extra 10 soles - it really does a much better job of explaining what we are looking at. Very interesting pieces divided in 3 areas: the main museum (perhaps 5-6 rooms), the erotic gallery, and visible storage. The surroundings are also very nice and there is a great fancy restaurant too. A big tip would be to come early: we got there at 10-ish and had a tour just for both of us; by the time we were going out there were lines for tickets and the museum was very crowded.

Lovely place amazing collection of Indigenous artifacts, beautiful displays, and the garden, just stunning small but packed full of wonderful art. It also has a large erotic art section, very Peruvian cultural art, but best to keep the kiddos out of that section. Very nice!

Beautiful museum of artifacts from ancient Peruvian civilizations, including ceramics, textiles, and metalwork. The exhibits are nicely curated, and the collection is huge, but for an entry fee of 50 soles I would've expected a bit more variety and some other content than just constant display cases with accompanying text. Very interesting, but after a while it gets a little boring.

Beside the main museum there's a separate exhibit for "erotic" artifacts, mainly pottery portraying sexually explicit scenes. It's included in the main ticket price. There's also a souvenir shop and a restaurant on site.

There are explanatory texts in several languages for all exhibits, so English speakers for example can easily follow along. There's also an audio guide available, but this we didn't try. We spent approximately two hours walking through the museum, stopping briefly at most exhibits.

🌟 An unforgettable experience—leave yourself plenty of time!

Visited on Tuesday, July 1, 2025 with reservations from 5–7pm. We arrived early but were overdue for dinner, so we hit the restaurant before exploring the museum. Though that left us only about an hour inside. Despite the short visit, every detail of the museum, restaurant, and grounds impressed me.

🍽️ The restaurant is beautifully designed—definitely a bit upscale for my “hole-in-the-wall” tastes, but still worth the stop. Prices are on the higher side.
🌺 The grounds are stunning, with vibrant flowers everywhere and photo-worthy views around every corner.
🏺 The museum exhibits are top-notch, A+. What can be said about this collection that hasn't already been said? The quality, detail, and condition of these artifacts that are hundreds and thousands of years old, are second to none. Simply extraordinary. I'd recommend 3-5 hours or more if you really want to absorb and appreciate everything. So I'll definitely be returning for another visit as 1–2 hours isn’t nearly enough.

🗣️ Guided tours in Spanish are available for 10 soles and last about an hour. They didn’t offer English tours during our visit, but I believe they do offer them. They provide self-guided audio devices in English for the same price—I'll try that next time because I'm a fan of moving at my own pace.

🎁 Gift shop: Prices are steep, but it's a welcome addition. Far too many sites in Peru lack gift shops and miss the opportunity to cash in on visitors after the experience. People want souvenirs and they're willing to pay for them!

📍 Overall: This is a must-see destination for anyone visiting Lima. Don’t rush it—plan time to explore, then unwind with a meal or drink afterward.

A lot of the museum is under renovation- but it was still worth the trip. We learned so much about Peru and how it won its independence.

The staff was very friendly but not many English speakers and the Spanish I practiced for did not help here. But still, not big issues.

Beautiful building as well.
Good show case in archeology history of Peru and Inca culture. Free admission is a plus. If have time see this one first,  then go see the laco museum. You will much be appreciated.

The museum is definitely still being remodeled and lots of areas are not available. It was free for English speakers because very little signage in English. No English audio guide was available. There are some QR codes and English translations in the second building.  Some interesting exhibits to see but challenging without translation or audio guide. Go if you are good with just walking around and looking at exhibits or feel like translating lots on your phone.

My wife and I were happy that we decided to visit this museum this week. A few sections are not accessible, but due to the recent APEC summit, they have decided to go all in and they are currently exhibiting a few pieces they never exhibited before. There are pieces not even Peruvians have seen yet so, quality over quantity is the key. Last chance to see them too, as the museum will fully close for renovations at the end of February, and will not reopen until 2027-28.
A real Tumi, several gold and silver pieces and the best preserved textiles we've had the chance to see, are only a few of the elements that make this a worthy visit. Additionally, this museum has the real Estele Raimondi, one of the most important peruvian monoliths that still exists.
To finish, you will also get to see a well preserved colonial mansion, with original floors and a beautiful garden.

Last notes:
1. There are two entrances to the museum. Start your visit through the second one, that leads to the "Casona". This is the one that has most of the things that can be seen at the moment. Once you finish there, you can go to the main one (way less things to see atm), but mandatory if you want to see the Estele Raimondi.
2. Most of the texts are not translated in English, but it is what you could expect when visiting a non-English speaking country. It is part of the experience when visiting a foreign country.
3. There are a few breweries near the museum you can visit after, especially the traditional Queirolo Tabern, which has traditional food and drinks.

Nice and quite place, good place for history lovers.
You don’t need to buy any tickets.
The best experience I’ve had! The man who owns this museum is so smart and filled with love and passion for his culture! If you are visiting Lima please take the time to visit this amazing museum!
It is an incredible place, it needs more diffusion :)
A must visit !! Really interesting
Its so pretty

The wonderful researcher Enrique Niquin has worked a lifetime, recovering the legacy of the COL-LIS - Collique, with humility but determination. The museum is a place that pays tribute to this ancient people, to our roots, and to the nobility of someone as brilliant as Niquin! Visit it soon!

A pre-Hispanic structure located between the districts of Carabayllo and Comas consists of almost three blocks of walls forming the shape of an L.
The Tungasuca wall, also known as the Colli epimurales (named after the Colli lordship that occupied the area), is in a state of severe deterioration due to the neglect of the district authorities.
Its structure has a wide base and a narrower upper section.
The archaeological site is partially neglected and loses its way through the nearby houses.
There is nothing here. Or at least it's closed. Even the Uber driver was confused.
Xd
Perfct
Very good service from the guys who work there. The place is very well set up for kids. We had a great experience ☺️
I went on Sunday and didn't even find a sign.

We took a bus to the flower market at the foot of the hill. Asked a policeman there how best to go up and if its safe. They suggested taxi. We took a tuk tuk. Nice ride going up through a community. Lovely view at the top. Stayed there about 20 minutes and a tuk tuk brought us back. I would have felt safe trekking down too.
Nice view, but you reach it over kind of favelas, so our uber driver was scared to leave us up there alone and waited for us go get us save back to the city center.
It’s a really nice place to enjoy the view over the city of lima👍🏻 Really special is when you go at night up there.

The view is not great but it's impressive to see the huge dimensions of Lima. The place is abandoned since there are no tourist buses going up there anymore. You can get a Taxi or Uber to bring you up. Make sure that the taxi is waiting, else you would have to wait a long time or descend by foot, which is not recommended as you would have to walk 30 minutes through the slums.
This is not for every tourist; it is only for those who want to see and experience all parts of the land. Be careful and cautious; Lima is mostly safe; I did not have any bad incidents…

Amazing place! Great collection. A must see for car fans. Iv been to similar places in Sweden and UK and this one is among the best. The guide was very knowledgeable and we could see how they restored the cars, the before and after, a motor, etc. Really good!!!

Amazing muesum with a really cool selection of cars that the owner has found. All the cars were found in Peru and restored before being put on display. A lot of them are very rare or limited in number. I highly recommend a visit if you are a car fan.

Entrance costs 20 soles and is in cash.

What a marvelous gem in a desolate place for fine autos.  This man has carefully collect and restored fine autos from all over the world since his youth.  Beautiful collection!  Worth the visit.  We even got to see the restoration shop in action, hand crafting parts that are no longer available.
Stunning collection of cars in amazing condition. The restorations of these cars is incredible, they look new.

One of the most beautiful car collections I ever seen. The owner is a great man.
You can get here by bus no OM57 from city center it cost 3/sol.
Well-appointed, well-maintained, and educational, even if you go for a short time, they can teach you enough to understand the topic.
Very nice and quiet, perfect to spend a good afternoon
Very friendly and nice service, it has interesting things to see if you like to learn and be curious.
A welcoming museum to take the family to learn more about our rich pre-Hispanic history.
This museum has no entrance fee and it has very beautiful pieces. There was also staff willing to guide you, giving useful information to help you understand this artist's creation.

Loved this place. To truly appreciated this museum, you need to have a basic understanding of abstracts in work of arts and an open mind to imagine. It's free to enter. You'll need vax card, ID, and mask.
A lot of fancy works there. Too good to just visit once. I’m definitely returning.

Abstraccionism 💕
Let your imaginación float And admire the masterpieces of this bolivian sculptor.

Fantastic charming museum in leafy area of San Isidro quarter. Highly recommend. Teresa kindly guided us in the museum and passionately showed us the masterpieces created by Marina Núñez Del Prado. Dante & Gabriel

This is a quick but fun stop. If you have 60 minutes to kill in San Isidro and want to see a little history, go here. Entry fee was 5 soles per person in August 2025.
The site is in a lovely residential part of San Isidro.

This is a relatively small pre-Incan site in Lima.  It is worth visiting if you are in the neighborhood, but there are better pyramid sites to see in Lima.  You can walk up the pyramid, and there are decent views.  The museum itself was a bit underwhelming. Still, it is an impressive piece of history in the middle of a modern city, so see it if you are nearby.
Interesting to visit although there is a limited amount of things to see

I walked here with a broken leg, and when I got here, they said the credit card machine was broken, and we cannot get in without cash. We just arrived to Peru and did not have it, and even though it's 5 soles, they would not help us. We had to take an Uber to our hotel and could not get in. Crutches and all, denied entry. We understand we aren't entitled, I get it...but a little heartless. Bad start to Peru.

Not an expensive visit but with the amount of info provided from just the signs (in English and Spanish), you’ll be done in 15-30 minutes. The guy in front of me at the ticket counter didn’t read at all and was in and out in under 10 minutes. Highly recommend you walk around outside of the site as well (free/before entry gates) as the places you can go within are quite limited.

Recommended for completing procedures related to women's rights, and they provide social support for soup kitchens. It also has an auditorium that seats 1,000 people. Next door is a recreational park for sports and children's play areas.

The meetings are a very good initiative, but the Municipality takes a long time until the public meets. And it requires everyone to be forward for the photos.
And there is no air conditioning.
It has a large, furnished cinema-style auditorium.
CONGRATULATIONS FOR THE PUBLIC ATTENTION MODULE, INCLUSIVE, EXCELLENT ATTENTION, HUMAN TALENT WITH PERSPECTIVE TAKING♥️✅✅
It is a nice place that allows for recreation and good family time.
Great museum collection! The space includes both permanent and temporary displays. Really enjoyed walking through the galleries and admiring the contemporary art. Worth visiting when in the area.

While the ongoing exhibit on Inca photographs by a local artist was good, the permanent collection was just housed in a big hall. Very little explanations. Overall a rather disappointing lay out and art works that were neither inspiring or interesting.
Great contemporary art museum with a good collection of Peruvian art. Special exhibitions as well.  Highly recommended.

It looks a well intentioned museum to highlight works of Peruvian artists. The building has large, very spacious exhibition rooms well lit from the natural light.

HOWEVER, collection/exhibition is very limited and has so narrow breath.

🫤 There’s complete lack of sculptures and/or 3D pieces.

* There MUST be a number of contemporary sculptors in Lima or nationwide, whose art are worth chasing after for exhibition here.

🫤 A lot of photographic exhibits are more of random shots of political events, lacking an artistic rendition of such events.

* The photos are VERY FLAT IMAGES rather than expressive imagery that would convey why the photographer was attracted by that instant in time.

* Many of the shots seem very elementary/rudimentary, lacking depths of focus.

*The photos FAIL TO EVOKE EMOTION, as such they seem misplaced for this museum.

🫤 Similarly, exhibitions of framed newspaper articles from the recent past are mere collages, like a hobbyist’s scrapbook. They FAIL TO CONVEY AN AESTHETIC rationale why they were put together.

😎 There’s a few of the paintings, especially the abstracts, that are worth the time for visual and intellectual feast.

A very interesting place with lots of art to see, it took us approximately 45 minutes to walk through the 3 zones. I recommend it if you like art and don’t have time to visit a large museum. You can also buy tickets on the spot.

A must see museum, composed of several buildings of religious and secular art, costumes, coins and daily items from the Spanish era. The grounds are also gorgeous and manicured for every detail. Do not miss this gem.
A nice museum if you appreciate architecture and garden design, but beyond that, I didn’t find it very engaging for the price.

Go for the architecture and the layout of the gardens, both of which are stunning. The art is an interminable display of yet more Christian allegory, heavy on the “constipated figurative” school, none of which is especially interesting if you’ve been to a single church at any point in your life.
Amazing story of powerful family and their home with amazing art history.  No photos allowed from inside, you must come see!

Lovely museum to step out of the hustle and bustle of Lima and return to a time when Peru was simpler and quieter. The house and grounds are magnificent and the wonderful colonial art adds to the refined atmosphere of this museum.

I really enjoyed the way the museum presents the work. You get to see Jade Rivera's progression from young graffiti artist to a more refined and nuanced perspective over the years. I don't know if I missed the most recent stuff or if 2022 is the last new works in the museum. I would have liked to see or at least read about the latest projects he might be working on. I was told with my ticket I could have a guided tour, but I chose to just wander through on my own. Perhaps that was a mistake on my part. The entrance was very reasonable at 15 soles.

This small museum dedicated to the work of Peruvian muralist Jade Rivera is definitely worth a visit. It gives an overview of his career and evolution of his style. Beautiful paintings and a lovely little gift shop. Cynthia was working during our visit and gave thoughtful and in depth answers to our questions about the artist. We spent about 45 minutes there- a great easy stop when you are exploring Barranco.

A very enjoyable experience to see the creative evolution of an artist from street art to art with striking details and powerful cultural stories.
Lots of work but will only require an hour or two.  Nice gift shop.

Beautiful works of Jade Rivera, showcasing his multiple talents of drawing, painting and sculpturing.
The exhibition is devided into several rooms, each devoted to a certain period in the life of the artist.
The museum staff is very friendly, happily providing explanations regarding the exhibition.
I was speechless & impressed. A safe quiet environment to enjoyed artist Jade’s journey in his career & personal life. Carefully curated with different works in each room. Bravo!

The Ministerio de Cultura (Ministry of Culture) in Lima, Peru, is the government body responsible for promoting and preserving the country’s cultural heritage, arts, and traditions. Located in the capital, the ministry oversees the protection of historical monuments, indigenous cultures, and artistic expressions. It also organizes cultural events, exhibitions, and educational programs. The Ministry plays a key role in fostering cultural development and preserving Peru’s rich history, including its ancient civilizations like the Inca.

Very nice museum, spacious with art to buy and art on exhibition.

The Cafe Concierto next door is beautifully designed and has some beautiful musical events from time to time.
Excellent place for holding art exhibitions and conferences. Spacious and beautiful. Easy to reach by public transport. Highly recommended.

Great space
Awesome snack bar with a phenomenal chicken salad sandwich.
There is not actually a collection about Peru; only an exibition of contemporary art. Free admission though but museum was very limited. Better check some other museums
I really like the service. I'm halfway through my underarm laser hair removal sessions and I felt very comfortable.
Starting at 5:30 there is a lot of easy traffic, 40 minutes to get in.
Good place, clean, tidy, obviously with a queue, but useful
Chvr until someone wants something, they go all out
Don't worry
Yes
A very beautiful place
I had a great time
Good place
Very good

Monumento al Soldado Desconocido is a poignant and thought-provoking memorial that pays homage to the unknown soldiers who sacrificed their lives for a greater cause. Situated in a serene and well-maintained park, the monument exudes a sense of solemnity and respect.

The design of the monument is both striking and evocative, capturing the essence of the anonymous heroes it commemorates. The intricate details and symbolism incorporated into the sculpture provoke deep reflection on the profound impact of war and the sacrifices made by countless individuals who remain nameless.

The surrounding landscape adds to the overall ambiance, providing a peaceful setting for contemplation. The well-kept gardens and pathways create a tranquil environment, allowing visitors to pay their respects in a setting that encourages quiet introspection.

What sets this monument apart is its ability to convey a universal message about the collective sacrifice of soldiers, transcending national boundaries. It serves as a reminder that, regardless of nationality or background, the human cost of conflict is shared by all.

Visitors will appreciate the informative plaques and displays that offer historical context, enriching the experience with a deeper understanding of the monument's significance. The accessibility of the site, along with clear signage, makes it easy for both locals and tourists to find and appreciate this meaningful tribute.

Monumento al Soldado Desconocido is more than just a physical structure; it's a testament to the enduring spirit of those who gave their all without recognition. Whether you come to reflect on the history it represents or simply to enjoy the peaceful surroundings, this monument is a must-visit for anyone seeking a meaningful and contemplative experience.

This was the final destination for my biking tour from Miraflores to Chorillos. You have a great view of the city and the ocean at the top. The slope could be a bit steep for some bikers, but manageable for most. I recommend this if you want to explore places outside Miraflores.

The view from Lima and the beach on the other side are amazing! We walked from the Herradura beach and although it was a rough climb, we really appreciated the view! You can also go there by taxi or moto taxi! Worth the ride in my opinion!
Absolutely great view and awesome spot for pictures. Highly recommend.
Great view of 6 Burroughs of Lima city.  Arrived here via bike.

We had an amazing time learning about the religious significance of Pachacamac throughout the centuries. The museum was a definite highlight; well laid out, informative, and with interpretive signs in both English and Spanish, which made the experience accessible and engaging. Walking through the archaeological sanctuary was enjoyable, though it wasn’t quite as visually spectacular as some other sites in Peru. Still, the overall experience was enriching and well worth the visit for those interested in pre-Columbian history and ancient Andean spirituality.

This sanctuary and museum is located around 1 hour from miraflores . I was impressed by the museum that although it is smaller you will enjoy learning about the culture then it has a restaurant clean restrooms and the huacas you can go by car or walk it will take 1 h or less depending on your own time and the general price is 15 soles less than 6 dollars

I was blown away by the scale and significance of Pachacamac. The archaeological sanctuary is expansive, with sweeping desert landscapes, coastal views, and remarkably well-preserved structures that speak to centuries of continuous occupation and worship. Walking among the ruins—especially the Temple of the Sun and the Painted Temple—you really feel the spiritual and historical weight of the site.

The on-site museum is excellent: modern, informative, and well-curated, with artefacts that add depth and context to what you see outside. Exhibits are displayed beautifully, and the signage (in both Spanish and English) helps paint a vivid picture of the cultures that once thrived here.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in Peru’s pre-Hispanic history. Come early, wear a hat, and give yourself time to explore—it’s absolutely worth it.

Super cool to see the history here and learn about the different cultures that developed it over the millennia. I definitely suggest taking the orange route - walking through the streets and getting the tour guide as well. Totally worth it! Cabify was like 59 soles for each way from Miraflores Lima (about an hour with traffic each way tho). There wasn’t anyone there when we went.

Pachachamac has a history dating back to 200 BC and it has influences from Lima, Wari, Ychma and Incas culture. It used to be a pilgrimage centre and Pachacamac was a feared god with power to cause earthquakes. The current site has a museum and the excavations from the  structures built centuries ago - Sun Temple, Pachacamac, Acllawasi. During Inca rule (the last kingdom before Spanish Colonialisation), many people user to visit this site as a pilgrimage and many pyramids were built here. Sun Temple is supposed to have quite an ideal location based on planets and it faces the sea. There was a school built for girls called Acllawasi where they were taught day to day routine work. The excavation work is still in progress here. Entry ticket is 15 Soles for regular route and 20 Soles for special route. It was great knowing about this much ancient history. If you are a history buff, then this site is a must visit in your Lima it itinerary. Guided tours are available in both Spanish and English and cost 50 Soles.

The bulding is not holding their main collection yet, but they have temporary exhibits. From June to December 2024 they are showing a wonderful exhibit of traditonal or "folk art" with extraordinary pieces from different parts of Perú. Pieces from well know masters of their craft, from the 20th and 21st century, with roots in milenial craft traditions. Highly recomended. Free entrance and free parking. A great addition to your Pachacamac Archeological site visit.

The future building of the national museum of Peru. Currently it is not fully operational, there are some few temporal exhibitions. They also show the 5 floor building (3 underground) and the roof as part of the visit. According to the guide, they are partially open so they can evaluate routes, capacity, interaction with public and private transportation and things like that. You can visit by free (but soon, they will start selling tickets) and arrive there by taxi, bus and waking and also in your car (they offer parking slots). Don’t forget to schedule your visit and show your covid vaccination card.
A fantastic architectural design, ready to expose the rich culture of Peru. Very friendly guides.
It's a huge museum and I'm sure it'll be amazing once it opens fully equipped
Great place to visit and and get in touch with the exhibition that are expose at the moment, also if you have the time, check the activities in the official website and enjoy your journey there

Here was great place than I expected.
We can know Pachacamac history.
And we can see wonderful view including desert and ocean.
It is little bit far from Lima city.
But it is worth to visit.
Well worth the visit. 1h to 2h to visit. Beautiful view across the landscape.

Best done with a local tour guide who can explain the historical relevance and facilitate you through the museum and artefacts. The site itself is spread out so if you do not prefer to spend a lot of time the tour guide with a car would save you a lot of time. Al in all a good history site to visit.
This site is where the oracle gave readings. A temple has some of the original red paint intact. There is a restored piece of the 5000 mile long Inka road. A must see.
Spectacular

The National Museum of Peru (MUNA) is one of the most emblematic works of the Peruvian State, built by the Ministry of Culture.

In 2014, the Ministry of Culture launched a competition for architectural ideas for the MUNA, and based on this initiative, construction of the building began in 2016. As part of this long journey, on December 29, 2020, through Supreme Decree No. 018-2020-MC, the President of the Republic, Francisco Sagasti Hochhausler, formalized the creation of the National Museum of Peru, fulfilling a long-held republican aspiration.

The MUNA's mission is to be a space for dialogue and encounter through the protection and appreciation of cultural diversity, emphasizing the relationships and connections between different cultural groups of Peruvians in their territory throughout history.

The museum's vision is to become a governing and coordinating entity for the country's museums, capable of responding to the demands of preserving, researching, and disseminating the nation's cultural heritage.

Welcome to MUNA!

I loved it. The infrastructure, the mini-exhibits, the games, and the guides' interaction with the people. It's still improving, but what I saw yesterday was really interesting; especially the science and technology exhibits, the oil zone, and the playground.
We went as a family: children, teenagers, adults, and seniors. We all enjoyed it.

An impressive work of architecture, an interactive museum with pre-Inca history. Spacious rooms, an elevator, and parking. Across from the Pachacamac Museum, soon to open, with free tours and a guide by appointment.
Beautiful place, our Peru is beautiful..!
Excellent place good experience

Beautiful collection, although a little repetitive.

The museum is split in two levels: the bottom has all the gold collection as well as ancient tools of (pre)Inca culture. The upstairs section contains a huge collection of weapons, samurai armour and swords, and more.

If you are into weapons, you will love the upstairs bit. The gold collection was impressive.

Fun-sized collection. In the arms side, there are guns, rifles, swords and uniforms from many different places. Even a sword that belonged to Sultan Mustafa II of Ottoman Empire.

On the gold side, the most interesting to me were the mummies and other burial related items. Lots of gold but not much extraordinary except a couple of primary pieces.

Lima has a lot of museums and based on your interests, you can visit them. I decided to visit this Gold Museum which has  a special exhibit of Golden artifacts. The entry ticket to this museum is 40 soles. They also have a Mummy exhibit which was quite fascinating. Apart from that there are arms exhibits. One hour is enough to visit this museum. You can hire a guide as well. I found the prices a bit higher though.

A global traveler’s immersion into Peru’s Golden Treasures. It’s a great museum, thanks to foresight and generosity of Sñr Miguel Mujica Gallo whose personal collection has become a national treasure 🇵🇪🇵🇪🇵🇪that now educates the world of ancient Peruvian cultures.

The collection is very well curated, with annotations of the periods and tribal identities 👏👏👏.

The golden artifacts illustrates why there was so much greed of the Imperial Conquistadors that drove them to enslave indigenous peoples of the Old World.

So varied golden treasures😎😎😎😎😎, from personal adornments to practical home utensils like cups and goblets to deities to tribal symbols including crowns and headgears.

In addition to the gold, the museum also carries pottery. Like the gold, each of the pottery is a tribal pride and of daily importance to peoples’ lives.

The other half of the museum is a curation of military arms/armaments and uniforms. Perhaps the most interesting are the medieval armory and the collection of daggers and swords.

Some of armory are pieces art themselves, the most eye catching are the collection of Japanese Samurai.

THIS NATIONAL TREASURE NEEDS MORE PUBLICITY. We only saw this by chance looking for things to do in Lima on Google.
Extensive collection of weapons and armor from around the world and across history. Far beyond Peru. The gold and pottery collection from Peru is impressive.
Nice little museum. No English, but still some great specimens to look at if natural/prehistoric history is your jam

One of the best gift shops I’ve ever been to: a great place to pick up unique upmarket goods by Peruvian designers and craftspeople. A must for discerning shoppers!

I absolutely loved my visit here and ended up getting some unique jewelry. You can easily spend multiple hours looking at all the rooms, so plan accordingly if you love to shop/browse.

The shop includes homewares, clothing, a jewelry room, stationary, toys and kids items, a small selection of foods, and even a courtyard cafe with bonsai trees for sale.

Service is second to none. Associates will take your selections to the cashier while you continue to shop. Beautiful gift wrap is included with all purchases on request.

Some reviews have mentioned that perhaps some of the craft items are cheaper elsewhere. That may be the case, but there are a lot of brands I didn’t see elsewhere and everything is of the highest quality and carefully curated.

Don’t miss this store to check off your gift list for the year!

It’s such a cute store but prices are pretty bougie too! Great cafe at the back. Worth seeing but if you’re getting souvenirs I’d say this may not be the place. But for one off limited edition items, it is!

Amazing place to visit and browse through their different rooms. Fabulous art, handcrafts and alpaca-wool clothing & a beautiful café in a leafy courtyard at the back that's hidden from the main street.
It's like visiting a museum, for free, but you can buy some really nice souvenirs.

Customer service was amazing but triple check the expiry dates of chocolate bars. The kiosk is outdoors so perhaps not perfect storage conditions? The bar I bought was bloomed and had lost a lot of flavour/texture/was near the end of its shelf life unfortunately.

We are an Argentine-Danish couple. We first met this horrible person when she came screaming at us—not talking, but yelling—telling us to leave the parking lot in front of her gallery, a PUBLIC place, without any signs prohibiting it, with the security guards patrolling all day without saying anything to us. For three months now, we have actively chosen to get to know and explore all of Peru, its landscapes, culture, and its people. We stay within the law, traveling, leaving dollars in the country at every place we visit, paying entrance fees to archaeological sites quoted in dollars, making purchases over 300 soles a week in supermarkets, buying tickets for buses, taxis, restaurants, cafes, excursions, laundromats, local crafts, museums… And yet, we had to endure this horrible being screaming in our faces that she doesn't want this kind of tourism, that we should leave, and she didn't stop kicking us out the whole time. Ma'am, if you have a problem, you talk things over, don't shout, especially not at those who consume culture and could have been your audience. We were there for three days; at no point did we camp out, take out furniture, or anything! We felt completely discriminated against, and there's no way back from that... And I remind you that in Argentina I also pay taxes, which go to the hospitals that our Peruvian brothers and sisters use 'for free,' BROKEN FACE! I recommend spending your time talking to your neighbor who has two campervans parked 24 hours a day in front of your gallery, instead of kicking out those who leave money in their country. I recommend people visit the Jade Rivera gallery and museum, an artist with beautiful works and a humble and heartfelt person whom we had the chance to meet. The murals around Barranco are also by Jade.
It's in a peaceful mansion. Today, at the beginning of May 2023, there's an impressive structure at the entrance.

I did end up getting something but his presence made me uncomfortable.

An important fact to note is that all the artists, designers, and artisans are Peruvian.
There are very modern, designer pieces, and other objects more traditionally inspired.
The place makes you realize the enormous Peruvian talent.
The service is very courteous and friendly, always willing to inform you. Recommended to simply explore or to pick up a unique piece.

Much like the experience of one other reviewer, during my visit here, my mother and I were followed around the store by a sales associate as we looked at the various items on sale. This place left a bad taste in my mouth, as when I first walked in, I asked that same sales associate kindly for the restroom, and after being told there wasn’t one, I left for Dedalo down the block to find one. When I came back to the store after going to Dedalo, I walked around and looked at all the items on sale. What caught my ear and left a bad taste in my mouth was that a lighter-skinned Peruvian woman who was also walking around was given access to their bathroom after I had been told there wasn't one. My visit to this store made me feel uncomfortable because of their racial profiling and discrimination.

Usually, visitors come to the place where the animals are at the end of the excursion. The alpacas are very cute, but they don't really like to be photographed, they turn away right away. Near the alpacas there is an enclosure with cuy. In my country they are called guinea pigs and are kept at home as pets, but in Peru they are eaten.

Don't waste your time. You won't see any llamas or alpacas, and you can't touch the ones they have. It's just a two-hour tour to get you into the Huaca Pucllana Museum. This is a two-hour tour. There are no alpacas or llamas at the zoo. It's a two-hour tour to get you into the museum!

We been there in Saturday right in the morning, it was very organized, very clean, a lot of places to buy food and souvenirs, it’s looks like the animals are getting good care, nice place to come and visit for people how like different zoos, the only reason I gave 4 stars and not 5 is that the toilet cubicles were without locks and lack of toilet paper 🧻.

Great experience seeing animals that are native to Peru, especially the ones in the Sierra and Selva: condors, vicunas, alpacas, variety of monkeys (including the smallest one in South America), otorongos (jaguars), other different large felines, ronsocos (capybaras), etc.
Recommend coming during weekdays when it is not as busy so you can snap better pictures of your favorite animals.
I was amazed.  I've been to several US zoos.  This one blows them away.  As an added bonus, they built the zoo around 500-2000 year old Huaca ruins.

Area of ​​the Legends Park where you will find spices from the Peruvian mountains, owl, condor, eagle, sheep, vicuñas, etc. Its accessibility is difficult for people with disabilities.

Very pretty and underrated, you must be well organized when you visit the park of legends, if you want to see everything, if you go through a specific area, etc.
The mountains are generally where I start and although many things improved due to the pandemic, the mountains did not need major repairs because it was always the best maintained area, whether the roads and walls are made of stone, I don't know how the mine is still the same. The only thing I would make a small change to is the staff that works at the mine, so rude.
It has some nice cassettes to take photos (entering through the waterfall, you continue straight ahead and at the first entrance to the right, right in the first hallway to your right they are there again on the stone wall).
There is a souvenir shop, the viewpoint which is very nice now that it is cleaner and more tidy.

An area with several small habitats for animals that inhabit the mountain region, including birds like the condor and domestic animals. Worthy of special mention are the large vicuña habitat that seeks to imitate the Pampas Galeras Nature Reserve and the model mine.
A nice experience to spend with the family.
Very nice zoo, the only withdrawal is that the toilets were without toilet paper and without locks 🔒

This large zoo provides family fun with plenty of zoned areas to discover. The ticket gates can be quite chaotic to navigate, but it is recommended to keep moving to find a less busy queue. Your belief system will dictate whether you wish to visit a zoo and may see some animals that seem stressed in their environment. There are various zones of types of animals to explore and the zoo is vast to discover. There are plenty of refreshment points and shops scattered around the zoo. The seal and monkey areas are particularly exciting for their playful natures. Overall it provides a good family experience that is hard to see in one day.
It was a fantastic part of the wider experience at parque leyendas, highly recommended

This park is an oasis for both humans and animals. Many people come to the park to relax, bringing blankets and food from the market stalls (right outside the entrance). Family-friendly and wheelchair accessible, there are food stalls and restaurants at reasonable prices.

Don't forget sunscreen and a hat. Regular sneakers are sufficient.

Highly recommended :-)

One of my favorite areas of the immense park of legends, it has animals from all over the world, although they are not many, there are enough to appreciate the majestic nature, you can see the heavy hippos, the no less heavy buffalo, the giraffe showing off its immense size, the zebras grazing, felines such as: tigers, there is also the Bengal tiger, you can also see the king of the jungle, the "Lion", you will also find a camel, ostriches and other animals. Highly recommended!
Animals from other countries, kangaroos, camels, rhinos, giraffes, zebras, buffaloes, zoricatas, etc.

Part of the Zoo that contains coastal animals, such as sea lions, flamencos, penguins and an aquarium. Great sights!

Although the spaces between species are somewhat separated, there is a good collection of coastal animals, and almost all of them are in exhibitions of an adequate size, although perhaps the guano birds exhibition needs to be enlarged.

They improved the distribution of spaces, and are in the process of opening new attractions that promise to be up to par, an unequivocal example of the country's coastal beauty in all its splendor. Take care of the place, take care of the animals, do not give them food, do not throw things at them, do not shout at them or hit the cages or glass, let's be responsible.

2022 marks the year of the park's takeoff, as it looks completely renovated. In addition to the original attractions—the little train, the motorboat, the Jungle area, the Coast, and the aquarium—a series of inflatable games have been added, the most notable being the Island in the Lagoon, the New Jungle, a new inflatable that allows for family fun.
What has improved significantly are the restaurants and the food offerings on the go. There is a wide variety of cuisine, ranging from traditional grilled chicken, regional dishes, and fast food stands and restaurants in the country-style Felinario area.
The renovated 5D cinema is operational, but it is actually a 3D cinema with some additional effects, water, and compressed air.

15 soles for admission, and there's also a charge for parking.
The zoo is super complete, with every animal you can imagine. The park is super clean.
The boat ride is paid separately, 10 soles for a wristband. It goes through a tunnel with a miniature Machu Picchu.

I recently visited Nautilus Aquarium and was really impressed by the dedication of the staff. It’s clear that the team here is passionate about marine life and does their best to create a great experience for visitors, even while working with limited resources. Every employee I interacted with was knowledgeable, friendly, and eager to share insights about the animals and conservation efforts, which really made the visit special.

One of the most exciting aspects of my visit was hearing about the upcoming exhibits! The plans for expansion and new habitats sound incredible, and I can’t wait to see how they enhance the experience in the future. It’s clear that the aquarium is moving in a really positive direction, and I love that they’re always looking to improve.

That said, some of the older exhibits and systems could use a little TLC. A few tanks showed signs of wear, and certain areas felt like they could benefit from updates. However, given the effort and enthusiasm of the staff, I have no doubt that they’re doing everything they can to maintain and improve the facility.

Overall, Nautilus Aquarium is a great place to visit, especially for anyone who loves marine life and wants to support an organization that truly cares about its animals and its mission. I’m excited to see how it evolves, and I’ll definitely be back to check out the new exhibits when they open!

I usually go on days when there are no crowds, so the service was immediate. They brought my order within approximately 7 to 10 minutes. I ordered a very spicy mixed ceviche (S/40), however, when I tried it, it wasn't spicy at all. I didn't complain because I didn't want to ruin my lunch, and they had to add rocoto cream so it would be moderately spicy. That was my solution. The space inside the restaurant is average. They play music at a moderate volume, which allows for conversation if you go with others. You can park your vehicle outside, but on a busy day, I doubt you'll find a space. Finally, I can say that their chicha morada is a 10/10, and I give the ceviche I tried a 6.5/10.

I don't know if it was due to lack of staff or what, but they delayed taking the order, so far it's normal, it's something that can happen, right? But at the time of bringing the plates, the dishes were not clean, it seemed as if they had been served on top of a dirty plate. The young lady was asked but she only managed to say "it's the juice from the ceviche." When I tried the ceviche, the fish had a bad flavor, it tasted like "fish", it had dark parts that are normally removed when making ceviche since it gives a different flavor, the cassava was hard, the onion was already purple, due to being cooked too long. The worst of all? The thing is that the dish was returned but they brought another one with other ingredients (I think it was octopus) while the order was always a "fish" ceviche. I paid for the dish yes, but when I approached to complain at the end they kept making excuses, to clarify the dish it cost 35 so, if it were a dish of 10 it would pass and that, because in a crouch you could find it for 8 soles. When you go to a restaurant you expect something good and it is no excuse to say that then you go to a good area, because the prices they give do not reflect the "quality" for which you pay.

The fish chicharrón (S/. 30) was a little salty for my taste but abundant. The sole ceviche (S/. 45) was very simple in flavor, and what I loved was the mixed chaufa rice, although they didn't serve me the fish nuggets (which were included in the chaufa) and I had to tell them that my plate was missing it, but they brought it soon after. The chicha morada (1 liter for S/. 12) was delicious and with all that for three people it was very abundant. The wait time was 15 minutes, but when it was time to pay, they tried to overcharge us because we ordered two jugs of chicha and the bill showed three jugs.
I always go to this place with my family, because we had a great time and in general everything is very good this time I went with my niece.
