The bridge serves as a pedestrian link between Barranco and Miraflores. In addition to the bridge, there are additional features such as platforms, paths, and restrooms, which adequately complement the infrastructure. As an aesthetic/sculptural element, the use of appropriate materials, both in terms of color and surfaces, was lacking; I don't see them as functional. The lighting should have been warm or neutral. The cycle path cannot be used by bicycle.

The best experience, security, cameras, people enjoying the excellent views. You have to walk quite a bit since the corridor is quite long, but if you take your time you can see everything. The bridge is beautiful, there are even drones monitoring for security. I recommend taking a walk there!

This bridge has been much criticized for its cost, construction time, and even its color, as it's the same color as the Popular Renewal political party, to which the current mayor of Miraflores, Carlos Canales, belongs. Some claim that the bridge's landscape design (it looks like recycled SEDAPAL pipes) shockingly disrupts the harmony. And be very careful if it's raining or if you're wearing smooth shoes, as the bridge's deck is made of polished cement. Oh, and if you didn't have enough light blue on your day, don't worry, you can marvel at the bollards once you step outside, which Canales sees as green, but I'll leave you with the image.
It is not only a pedestrian bridge, it is a very useful tourist bridge, helping with rapid transit between the two districts of Barranco and Miraflores.
Beautiful in cold weather, and if there's a strong breeze in summer, it must be lovely.

This is a nice spot to take some panoramic photos of the Lima coastline.  There are public bathrooms on the walk to the lookout point, and there is a crossing to the beach if you are interested, although the beach is not great here.

- Good place with great views
- I don’t think they have a proper beach or clean water that you can go into it but they have parks by the water. So, it’s a good area to visit in the evening by the sunset.
- They have good restaurants too.
Nice view, good place for pictures, it is free to visit
Nice view when it's sunny, quite average when it's grey.

It's an excellent vantage point for enjoying a panoramic view of the beach. It has a relaxed, bohemian atmosphere, surrounded by urban art, trees, and street music, giving it a very special feel. It's ideal for strolling, taking photos at sunset, or simply sitting and admiring the scenery.

This bridge itself is pretty standard - about 40 feet long with no major views to speak of. But that's not what makes it special. The real treasure is the shops surrounding it, filled with unique art designs, cool jackets, t-shirts, and bags. It's evolved beyond just a marketplace - it's now a hub for creative expression. While the restaurants nearby are okay, they're not the main draw. The real highlight is the eclectic mix of art and shopping that makes this area worth exploring.

At the Bridge of Sighs, we lucked out-the garúa had faded, leaving us with clear blue skies and a warm breeze. According to legend, if you hold your breath while walking across the bridge, your wish will be granted; and if you cross it with your lover, you are said to be blessed with eternal love. The surrounding area is delightful, with a cute park, vibrant murals, and intriguing street art that make it a perfect spot to wander and explore. Lovely area to walk around and explore or take your pup out to enjoy.

This is a beautiful tourist attraction in Barranco, Lima, Peru. Don't believe the legend that if you hold the hand of the one you love and cross the bridge while holding your breath, if you make it to the other side you will be together forever... total and utter lie 🤣🤣 Other than that there is a beautiful spot, art, food, and more to see and or eat. It also  leads down to the beach.
It’s nice area but unfortunately not as nice as I expected. Church is not lighted and that’s a pity. Would make pictures much more beautiful. Murals are nice.
Great lil artsy area and the vendors there are nice and not pushy. Would have loved to visited in the evening when the bars were open as I think there’s music then.

The view from here is GORGEOUS!!! The area is well kept, very clean, and you'll always see Police riding around. Felt very safe. This whole area, if you keep walking, is great all along the coast to walk, ride your bike, and enjoy the sunset. You'll also see a lot of couples sitting or enjoying a small little picnic and taking pictures.
A small patch of the malecon has been planted with shrubs and flowers that attract butterflies; in particular the Monarch. It's lovely!
So cute I saw one butterfly due to winter time

It's a park like any other, with flowers like milkweed, which is food for butterfly larvae, and more grass than in traditional parks. However, it's poorly maintained and has broken signs; it looked like it was being renovated.

It’s a great little park on Av. Sucre. Next to the best pizza in Lima. I wouldn’t make a special trip to come and see the cross, but would combine it with a visit to the archeological museum and Plaza Bolivar.

The cross is where the park gets its name. It dates to 1579 and was where pilgrims and travellers would come to ask for safe passage across Peru and around the rest of the Americas.

This monumental cross, erected in 1579 by Catholic missionaries, stands as a historical landmark. Travelers would stop here to pray for protection on their journey to the port of Callao, a route that was once plagued by bandits.
Cool, and awesome history, but very tiny, kinda dirty, park.   Worth the photo op if you're in the area but not much else. Don't make a special trip.
Safe and quiet place
Ok

The Larco Museum in Lima is one of Peru’s finest museums and a must-visit for anyone interested in history and culture. Housed in an 18th-century colonial mansion, it features an outstanding collection of pre-Columbian art, including ceramics, textiles, metalwork, and jewelry from ancient civilizations like the Moche, Nazca, and Inca.

One of its highlights is the world-famous gallery of erotic pottery, which is both fascinating and unique. The museum also offers beautifully curated exhibits with clear explanations in multiple languages, making it easy to understand Peru’s rich cultural heritage. The gardens and café add to the experience, creating a relaxing atmosphere after exploring the galleries.

Perfect for culture lovers, history buffs, and anyone wanting a deeper understanding of Peru before (or after) visiting its archaeological sites.

This museum isn't very big but it has amazing pieces. I would really recommend a guided tour which is offered at an extra 10 soles - it really does a much better job of explaining what we are looking at. Very interesting pieces divided in 3 areas: the main museum (perhaps 5-6 rooms), the erotic gallery, and visible storage. The surroundings are also very nice and there is a great fancy restaurant too. A big tip would be to come early: we got there at 10-ish and had a tour just for both of us; by the time we were going out there were lines for tickets and the museum was very crowded.

Lovely place amazing collection of Indigenous artifacts, beautiful displays, and the garden, just stunning small but packed full of wonderful art. It also has a large erotic art section, very Peruvian cultural art, but best to keep the kiddos out of that section. Very nice!

Beautiful museum of artifacts from ancient Peruvian civilizations, including ceramics, textiles, and metalwork. The exhibits are nicely curated, and the collection is huge, but for an entry fee of 50 soles I would've expected a bit more variety and some other content than just constant display cases with accompanying text. Very interesting, but after a while it gets a little boring.

Beside the main museum there's a separate exhibit for "erotic" artifacts, mainly pottery portraying sexually explicit scenes. It's included in the main ticket price. There's also a souvenir shop and a restaurant on site.

There are explanatory texts in several languages for all exhibits, so English speakers for example can easily follow along. There's also an audio guide available, but this we didn't try. We spent approximately two hours walking through the museum, stopping briefly at most exhibits.

🌟 An unforgettable experience—leave yourself plenty of time!

Visited on Tuesday, July 1, 2025 with reservations from 5–7pm. We arrived early but were overdue for dinner, so we hit the restaurant before exploring the museum. Though that left us only about an hour inside. Despite the short visit, every detail of the museum, restaurant, and grounds impressed me.

🍽️ The restaurant is beautifully designed—definitely a bit upscale for my “hole-in-the-wall” tastes, but still worth the stop. Prices are on the higher side.
🌺 The grounds are stunning, with vibrant flowers everywhere and photo-worthy views around every corner.
🏺 The museum exhibits are top-notch, A+. What can be said about this collection that hasn't already been said? The quality, detail, and condition of these artifacts that are hundreds and thousands of years old, are second to none. Simply extraordinary. I'd recommend 3-5 hours or more if you really want to absorb and appreciate everything. So I'll definitely be returning for another visit as 1–2 hours isn’t nearly enough.

🗣️ Guided tours in Spanish are available for 10 soles and last about an hour. They didn’t offer English tours during our visit, but I believe they do offer them. They provide self-guided audio devices in English for the same price—I'll try that next time because I'm a fan of moving at my own pace.

🎁 Gift shop: Prices are steep, but it's a welcome addition. Far too many sites in Peru lack gift shops and miss the opportunity to cash in on visitors after the experience. People want souvenirs and they're willing to pay for them!

📍 Overall: This is a must-see destination for anyone visiting Lima. Don’t rush it—plan time to explore, then unwind with a meal or drink afterward.

A lovely place to visit with kids, there is a free playground, a kid´s bathroom, various food, drink and snack options, an electric train ride possibility, a lagoon wiht paddle boats and an arc from which you have a great view over the surroundings.

Such a fun place to take kids! It’s about 30
minutes from San Isidro neighborhood but well worth it. From the adorable train ride, the lake boats and ducks, and the amazing bouncy fun zone that is massive, there is so much to do here for almost 3 hours. It’s sprawling and well landscaped, it’s truly a nice place to visit with lots to do. It feels non-touristy and more of a local gem.

This place is not that big. But big enough to pass a good time. Have a theatre, a small train going around , a beautiful arch that is Spanish ottoman architecture, some beautiful fountains, lots  of different birds, a museum, benches, coffee shops and  entertainment for  kids, is free entrance, I went for  a walk with my father like doing some shopping and we were lost  at this wonderful place. Highly recommend to spend some time in here.
A lovely family place. Enjoyed a little serenity of feeding the birds and watching kids enjoy the playgrounds.
I love it! Cute not too big not too small. Excellent to have a relaxed afternoon with the family.
Excellent place to walk your dogs (always keep them on a leash because there are children playing, don't forget to pick up after them💩💩💩🐕).
Good route, there's an area with a view of the entire city. The path is a bit dark and steep, but you can get there easily.

I went with a cycling group called Biker People. It was an internal competition. It's excellent for cycling and running, as it's uphill, and it's very beautiful during the day, as you can see much of it from above. That's for sure.
If you go at night, always go in groups of five or more people, as it's a bit dark and dangerous. There is security from the security guards, but it's better to be safe than sorry.
A place to exercise early in the morning without problems and good slopes
From this viewpoint, you can see the vast difference between poor Lima and modern Lima. You can see a large part of Lima from a great height. The place is quite lonely.

Good place to walk with your family. Ample space for your kids to run around. My toddler had a blast. I would recommend close toed shoes or shoes with good treads because it can get slippery and you may fall if you aren't careful or if you have mobility issues. It is mostly stroller or wheelchair accessible.
Nice place to come for a walk!
A very beautiful place to visit. You can walk around the lagoon with the ducklings. The walk seemed a bit short, but the view was very pleasant.
Friendship Park is a great place to have fun alone or with others. It has many attractions, making it highly recommended for everyone.
Nice place to be with family
Nice green oasis in the middle of the city. It's full of public exercise machines. It's a nice quiet place to relax or make some physical activity
Great place! It's an ecological option for a while, you can have a great view of the city of surco. Nice spot for running and jogging.

This is a very nice park to walk in. The only downside was when the Seranazgo (neighborhood police) drove their vehicle into the park and instead of politely asking people to move off the path they initiated their warning siren. How stupid is that? Welcome to Peru....the land of noisy and inconsiderate people.

I really like what they have done to this park. The hill contains numerous pathways, taking you through many native trees and flowering shrubs. A good place to watch birds in Lima. There is a flat area with grass at the eastern edge of the park for picnics.
Good place to walk and workout among nature. Great view of sunset during summer time. Free entrance. It's also a good playground for children. Many families visit it on Sundays. Highly recommended.
Really cold water on a cloudy day. Hard to access because of stairways. Needs more upkeep

This beach is private...it is located behind the Morro, and can be reached via the Spider Pass, which is reached by walking along the rugged coast from the Horseshoe, bordering the cliffs of the Morro...on this beach there are vestiges of a tower from the time of the war between Chile and Peru...

The route to La Chira via La Herradura beach is adventurous and of medium risk. The beach itself is pretty, clean, the sea is rough. I haven't seen any swimmers. It doesn't have any services and the AAHH population is at the back on the hill. I don't know how safe it is.
An adventure to get to this beach, I definitely had a lot of fun
I went for a run on this beach and spent a pleasant moment of peace and tranquility. The sound of the beautiful sea and the absence of people allows it to be clean.

I love walking from San Miguel to this spot in Chorrillos! It's a bit secluded and a little bit steep of a climb, but the view is fantastic. Close by are the planetarium, the statue of Christ of the Pacific, and the higher points of the communication antennas at about 1.2k meters altitude. Be sure to take water with you if you go on up from the cross tower, as it's not always available. Many bikers use the great trails out in the morro.

This place is really cool. It provides a good lookout of the ocean and a good bit of Lima. The cross is pretty cool when lit up at night, however, this is a pretty sketchy place to be at night. I would only recommend being there at night if you are with a pretty large group. We were in a group of 5 and were warned by a kid that if we walked up the road much further from here, we'd definitely get mugged. It makes for nice pics though, so it could be worth it :)
Nice view
Spectacular scenies and view of Lima Baie
Cool view and nice roads for training up and down.

Our English speaking guide was wonderful. We learnt so much. The staff do a fantastic job looking after the reserve. Plenty of birds and other wildlife to see.

You can only explore the reserve with a guide. I recommend booking the boat tour.
Relax
Magical nature

I really expected much more from this place. The hike isn't much, as it's quick and there isn't much to see along the way. The most worthwhile option is the catamaran ride, which costs extra and is where you can actually see a few more birds, although I don't know if it was when I went in late May when there were few more because it was autumn. The most abundant are the red-crested pochards and vultures, which were abundant. Admission is by group, and in my case, it took a while because there were only two guides.
The wetland, because they indicated it's not a swamp, is organized and clean. But for the entrance fee plus the extras you have to pay, it seems expensive to me, as what you'll see isn't dazzling. You'll see more birds in the adjacent areas and in that neighborhood, which is on the side, called Brisas de Villa.

It's very expensive for entertainment. Note that children under 5 also get bored quickly.

This weekend, I had the honor of participating in the Pantanos de Villa Wetland Cleanup Day, organized by the Municipality of Lima and PROHVILLA. 🌿

This experience not only allowed me to contribute to the care of a vital ecosystem for Lima, but also to connect with other people committed to the environment.

Furthermore, this activity is part of my participation as a volunteer in the "I, an Environmental Promoter 2025" program of the Ministry of the Environment (MINAM) 🌎✨, a space where young people take on the challenge of building a greener and more just country from within our communities.

This is a big joke. They will force you to have a guide who doesn't know well his birds for 30 or 50 soles and will limit your time in the reserve. Summary, you end up with a noisy group with a ridiculously short boat trip and miss the birds.
Very nice tour through the natural park, worth it!

The Hidden Grotto of Chorrillos, the place is very beautiful, it is worth the effort that has to be made to get there, but it is worth it. It is a 30 to 40 minute path from La Chira Beach, along the cliff, this path is a little dangerous, in most sections, so you have to do it calmly, in the area apart from the Grotto, you will find many caves, preferably visiting in a group.
Calm water and rather clean beach during weekdays. In summer it gets really crowded but nice and relaxed
Nice beach and fish market

A very nice place. The municipality organizes sports activities. It's recommended to go in the mornings rather than in the afternoons. Although there aren't many restaurants nearby, the only one is the seafood restaurant next door. If you want to eat something else, you have to walk up several blocks to barely find a restaurant. And at the main entrance, on the left side as you enter, there's a very, very neglected area.

I can't understand anyone who likes the beach.  Firstly, right on the street, crowded and extremely loud. Apparently everyone wants to be the best DJ and turns up the boombox, regardless of whether anyone wants to hear it or not. Umbrella costs 30 soles per day. Some beach vendor is shouting every minute. So you can't relax there.

One of Peru's most beautiful popular beaches. It's part of the Costa Verde circuit, and I recommend visiting Monday through Friday, starting at 4 p.m., as it's very crowded on Saturdays and Sundays. Photo: @miguelmejiacastro

We had a wonderful day. Perfect place to spend the day with kids in Lima. We went as a family group ages from 2-17 kids/teens and 42-74 adults. Everyone had a great time with games, rides, the pools, and waterslides. We also enjoyed visiting the farm animals. We spend >6h and didn't see everything (mostly because we spend a lot of time in the waterpark).

Such a cute place to visit with the kiddos, a lot of restrictions around pools unlike waterparks in other countries, e.g no walking with shoes or must have bathing suits on before walking inside pool area and no using hot tub after 4pm on weekdays, but putting those aside definetely makes it worth going with the kids for a nice outing.
A small amusement park. They've got some animals, and you can feed them food you buy at the park, so that was nice. It's not in a good part of town though.
More than worth it!!! Only a $20 all access pass!!!! Lots of fun and big!!! The earlier you arrive the best it is to take advantage of everything there is to do in there!!!
This was a nightmare, they asking you id, even if you have kid they don’t let you bring food for them, one hour to enter, they don’t allow you anything.
Nice place and good view.

Total chaos, an elderly manager over 80 years old, his secretary is a street vendor who sells at the door. Total improvisation. This is my third Sunday because they open whenever they want at 11 am and there are no tickets. I posted a complaint because on social media they claim that tickets are sold just before the show, but that's not the case. Children are the most disadvantaged. Tickets cost 10 soles even though the ticket says "donation S/6." We got a third shift at the insistence of a group of people. That day there were easily more than 120 people, and this is a private association. A lot of money comes in without declaring income.

Excellent site and the virtual exhibition is a great audiovisual breakthrough of what the cosmos is like with its infinite number of galaxies... Go see it and its museum is recommended for the general public.

At first, it seemed like a strange plan, but we really had a great time. The show was exciting (it's like a simulation), and the exhibits with telescopes, aliens, and more were great, especially for the kids. Plus, the view of the Sun's Head is incredible 💯👽🚀☄️
You can go up by car or on foot (the climb is quite tiring, but worth it).
P.S. The shows are on Sundays (one at 11:45 and the other at 12:45). It gets crowded, so it's best to arrive early).

A wonderful experience. I went with my then 4-year-old son. I would go again at least once every year and a half.
The dome you enter is small, and the explanations are very good, as is the music selection. They leave you with a few questions or brief inquiries so you can personally search for more information, and that's invaluable because it inspires you to want to know more.

It has a small museum where you can take photos.

Monumento al Soldado Desconocido is a poignant and thought-provoking memorial that pays homage to the unknown soldiers who sacrificed their lives for a greater cause. Situated in a serene and well-maintained park, the monument exudes a sense of solemnity and respect.

The design of the monument is both striking and evocative, capturing the essence of the anonymous heroes it commemorates. The intricate details and symbolism incorporated into the sculpture provoke deep reflection on the profound impact of war and the sacrifices made by countless individuals who remain nameless.

The surrounding landscape adds to the overall ambiance, providing a peaceful setting for contemplation. The well-kept gardens and pathways create a tranquil environment, allowing visitors to pay their respects in a setting that encourages quiet introspection.

What sets this monument apart is its ability to convey a universal message about the collective sacrifice of soldiers, transcending national boundaries. It serves as a reminder that, regardless of nationality or background, the human cost of conflict is shared by all.

Visitors will appreciate the informative plaques and displays that offer historical context, enriching the experience with a deeper understanding of the monument's significance. The accessibility of the site, along with clear signage, makes it easy for both locals and tourists to find and appreciate this meaningful tribute.

Monumento al Soldado Desconocido is more than just a physical structure; it's a testament to the enduring spirit of those who gave their all without recognition. Whether you come to reflect on the history it represents or simply to enjoy the peaceful surroundings, this monument is a must-visit for anyone seeking a meaningful and contemplative experience.

This was the final destination for my biking tour from Miraflores to Chorillos. You have a great view of the city and the ocean at the top. The slope could be a bit steep for some bikers, but manageable for most. I recommend this if you want to explore places outside Miraflores.

The view from Lima and the beach on the other side are amazing! We walked from the Herradura beach and although it was a rough climb, we really appreciated the view! You can also go there by taxi or moto taxi! Worth the ride in my opinion!
Absolutely great view and awesome spot for pictures. Highly recommend.
Great view of 6 Burroughs of Lima city.  Arrived here via bike.
I liked the place and the fact there are many restaurants you can visit. Unfortunately, there are not many places nearby you can visit but they are quiet spaces to go with your family or friends.
Very sunny, clear, safe and people with distance. I suggest this park.
Nice place goormet place to eat
Important square on the district of Chaclacayo.
Beatiful place
Lovely park for a stroll or to take the kids.
Lmao
Beautiful park , nice place to be with the kids
One of the best parks around
Beautiful park for the family fun

Great hike in Los Olivos (north of Lima).  You can take a taxi to the base or walk up the street from the Thomas Vale bus station.

At the end of the road (dead end) turn right and then take the stairs on the left up the hill and follow the arrows.

Great views of the city.  It can be very hot after 9:30am so be sure to bring lots of water.

Going up is fairly easy, however if you decide to go past the big rock outcrop, it can be a little difficult coming back down.   As well, not all of the trail is public - part is owned by the Army so trek at your own risk.

If you use Strava, you can see the trails that most people use.

I arrived there to access and do a Trek to the Lomas de Amancaes, Lomas de Independencia and the Mirador. I didn't know they were planting trees there, a very good initiative from whoever is doing it and promoting it, in a few years it will have been rescued and created a green lung within our concrete jungle.
Very nice place to walk and relax with the family
A good place for trail running and hiking, at this time it fills with greenery due to the humidity 💚
It is very pretty since we have a beautiful view
It has a good collection of one of the best animes and has won a record guiness twice. It is just a room in the third floor. It was exciting if you a fan of Saint Saiya of course.
If you are in Lima and you're a Saint Seiya follower, this place is a must to visit, very kind and nice  people will guide you, I will be back there.

Free museum dedicated to the largest saint Seiya collection in the world according to the Guinness world records.
Lots of toys and memorabilia.
Very interesting
Very legal
Historical atitude which explain many more about city
A nice walk with a good view from above of the surrounding area of La Molina. Plenty more archaeological discoveries to be made!
This is a place to bring your children and also to visit the archeological site called "Huaca" a huge park with a soccer and basketball court.
One of de best places to visit when in Lima, 5 star restaurant and ancient peruvian history.
One of the best places to visit when you're in LIMA.
Clean park. Only one open gate on south-western side.
Decent views from the top but bit of an ugly trail
It’s OK for reaching the sun light

A great place for trekking and trail running. It can be very foggy in winter, but in summer it's quite warm, and the sunrise is beautiful. In the right season, you can see the cloud cover! It's a spectacular sight.
I recommend bringing plenty of hydration and snacks for the hike, as it can be tiring if you're not used to physical exertion.

A very good route for those who enjoy trekking and trail running. There isn't much fog and it's usually always foggy, but the scenery is still captivating. It's a very tiring route if you're not used to hiking uphill. It's recommended to bring a charged cell phone in case you get lost and have an unexpected event. The phone signal is good even at the highest point.

The trek is demanding on the way up. Wear appropriate shoes and clothing. I visited during the foggy season, and even though it was foggy, the sun also shone at times, so it's a good idea to bring sunscreen.
Good food. Excelent view
It is my sanctuary, my religion, my people, mystical place, health
Farfan's bunker is nothing in comparison
Spacious, with various atmospheres, comfortable lounge areas, a variety of drinks, and music. A well-deserved 5 stars. Excellent place to celebrate with friends.
A very nice place to be with friends and family
This place as peaceful as the sound of the sea. You can do exercise there like run. It isn't crowded and it's secure.
Chevere
Great place...
Petfriendly
There is no space for children, a small park in a very closed place.
Ok
Monce

A nice quiet and well-entertaining park. Ideal for going out for a while with the family or cooling off with fresh air at night. It has a small structure for the kids and also has a gym area with some simple machines. Closes at night at 9:00 PM. The place is safe and quiet.
It has a roundabout where many people come to dance, aerobic, and kids with roller skates. In another area with sports equipment, up and down, and children with their games.
Since my childhood the best place. Gym well maintained by the neighbors. If you go with your dog, pick up after yourself because children always play (:

This is one of my favorite places. It is a beautiful park and is well-maintained. Certain times of the day/evening are busier, and there are usually a lot of wedding and quinceanera photographers. It's fun to watch though -- a lot of beautiful gowns.

Parque de la Felicidad was designed to cover and protect Surco River that crosses that area. It has a biophysical water treatment plant, that includes the use of water hyacinth to extract heavy metals that are potentially present in Surco River water. Good place for an academic visit with students. It is under the administration of San Borja City Hall (Municipalidad de San Borja).
Look, I know it's a popular spot to take photos but it was absolutely trashed. The sidewalks were nasty and the "lake" is gross, it's literally green.
Lovely park with fountains, very well kept gardens and children’s climbing frames
Really beautiful park, clean and well maintained. However, a lot of people go there to take professional pictures for weddings and ceremonies that make it a little bit crowded

We had an amazing time learning about the religious significance of Pachacamac throughout the centuries. The museum was a definite highlight; well laid out, informative, and with interpretive signs in both English and Spanish, which made the experience accessible and engaging. Walking through the archaeological sanctuary was enjoyable, though it wasn’t quite as visually spectacular as some other sites in Peru. Still, the overall experience was enriching and well worth the visit for those interested in pre-Columbian history and ancient Andean spirituality.

This sanctuary and museum is located around 1 hour from miraflores . I was impressed by the museum that although it is smaller you will enjoy learning about the culture then it has a restaurant clean restrooms and the huacas you can go by car or walk it will take 1 h or less depending on your own time and the general price is 15 soles less than 6 dollars

I was blown away by the scale and significance of Pachacamac. The archaeological sanctuary is expansive, with sweeping desert landscapes, coastal views, and remarkably well-preserved structures that speak to centuries of continuous occupation and worship. Walking among the ruins—especially the Temple of the Sun and the Painted Temple—you really feel the spiritual and historical weight of the site.

The on-site museum is excellent: modern, informative, and well-curated, with artefacts that add depth and context to what you see outside. Exhibits are displayed beautifully, and the signage (in both Spanish and English) helps paint a vivid picture of the cultures that once thrived here.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in Peru’s pre-Hispanic history. Come early, wear a hat, and give yourself time to explore—it’s absolutely worth it.

Super cool to see the history here and learn about the different cultures that developed it over the millennia. I definitely suggest taking the orange route - walking through the streets and getting the tour guide as well. Totally worth it! Cabify was like 59 soles for each way from Miraflores Lima (about an hour with traffic each way tho). There wasn’t anyone there when we went.

Pachachamac has a history dating back to 200 BC and it has influences from Lima, Wari, Ychma and Incas culture. It used to be a pilgrimage centre and Pachacamac was a feared god with power to cause earthquakes. The current site has a museum and the excavations from the  structures built centuries ago - Sun Temple, Pachacamac, Acllawasi. During Inca rule (the last kingdom before Spanish Colonialisation), many people user to visit this site as a pilgrimage and many pyramids were built here. Sun Temple is supposed to have quite an ideal location based on planets and it faces the sea. There was a school built for girls called Acllawasi where they were taught day to day routine work. The excavation work is still in progress here. Entry ticket is 15 Soles for regular route and 20 Soles for special route. It was great knowing about this much ancient history. If you are a history buff, then this site is a must visit in your Lima it itinerary. Guided tours are available in both Spanish and English and cost 50 Soles.

O Santuário de Pachacamac era cercado por muralhas, que se constituíam em sua principal  linha de defesa, formada principalmente por enorme muros e bastiões que possuíam a finalidade de proteger o local de possíveis ataques externos, também servia para controlar o acesso aos prédios, templos e setores mais importantes.
O Santuário possuía outras muralhas internas que protegiam os prédios e dividiam os tipos de atividades no local e além de facilitar a defesa do local de eventuais invasões, também permitia controlar o acesso de peregrinos e viajantes aos templos e locais sagrados, através de postos de controle existentes nos portões ao longo da Calle Norte-Sur.
Evidências encontradas no local indicam que a cidadela, fundada por volta de um mil a um mil e quinhentos anos atrás, reunia grandes centros cerimoniais, prédios administrativos e militares e concentrava grande número de habitantes.
A área total do sítio arqueológico ocupa quatro hectares, dos quais apenas um pouco mais de 20% foram escavados, no local atualmente funciona um museu que guarda objetos, cerâmicas e estátuas encontradas na escavação do sítio arqueológico e também templos, pirâmides, edificações administrativas, militares, prédios residenciais, comerciais e cemitérios, todos  construídos em barro, sobre fundações feitas com grandes blocos de pedra retirados do Rio Lurín, em torno do qual, floresceu a cultura lima.

Here was great place than I expected.
We can know Pachacamac history.
And we can see wonderful view including desert and ocean.
It is little bit far from Lima city.
But it is worth to visit.
Well worth the visit. 1h to 2h to visit. Beautiful view across the landscape.

Best done with a local tour guide who can explain the historical relevance and facilitate you through the museum and artefacts. The site itself is spread out so if you do not prefer to spend a lot of time the tour guide with a car would save you a lot of time. Al in all a good history site to visit.
This site is where the oracle gave readings. A temple has some of the original red paint intact. There is a restored piece of the 5000 mile long Inka road. A must see.
Spectacular
Ancient ruins near Lima Peru. The guide we had was wonderful.  It was very interesting.
Interesting place in the middle of the city, worth a visit. Tours are only guided, but start whenever people are and in English and Spanish. Both entrance and tour are free of charge!
Looks interesting but was closed when I arrived.  From the outside looks fairly large.  They may be doing restorations/upgrades to the site.
The tour was very informative and great views, too!
Nice guided tour of the small ruins in the middle of the Magdalena district of Lima
It's a place to spend time with family, I love it.

Huaca San Miguel was the setting for a beautiful ritual offering to the earth, as part of the Ychsma experience, a nighttime tour hosted by the Parque de las Leyendas.
It's an ideal setting to learn about Lima's first settlers and a ritual to thank Mother Earth for all she offers us.
Visit the Parque de las Leyendas to be nourished by knowledge, history, and tradition.

I loved visiting Huaca San Miguel and learning a little more about Peruvian culture from the guides.
Recommended!
A very interesting place to visit with the family, with interesting pre-Hispanic architecture.
Huaca inside the park, not very crowded, with life-size statues of its former inhabitants.
It's located within the Park of Legends. A wonderful experience. It allows you to learn more about the Ychsma culture.
Can't be seen from outside
It's amazing

Sierra and Mining
Although not widely visited, the Sierra area near Huaca Tres Palos preserves the charm of the riches its mountains provide. Thanks to the efforts of the mining sector, a mineshaft has been recreated, allowing visitors to see firsthand how a mine is exploited in the Peruvian Andes. In addition, a well-built model shows what an open-pit mine is like, a truly unique experience for those who haven't had the good fortune to experience it firsthand.
Huaca Tres Palos, ceremonial center of the Yshma culture...
Interesting, I had not realized that within the Parque de las Leyendas there were so many Huacas and they are all recovered and very well maintained.
Beautiful place, very impressive, and nice for those who like history

A nice zoo to visit while in lima. Enclosures are well maintianed and plenty of animals to see. Majority of enclosures where impressive although a few bigger animals could do with better designed encloaures. Price is good and place gets busy fast. Alot of peruvian secies kept that ypu would not see in wild.

We been there in Saturday right in the morning, it was very organized, very clean, a lot of places to buy food and souvenirs, it’s looks like the animals are getting good care, nice place to come and visit for people how like different zoos, the only reason I gave 4 stars and not 5 is that the toilet cubicles were without locks and lack of toilet paper 🧻.

I went on a Sunday, it was crowded. I was afraid it would be impossible to walk around the park, even though the experience was nice after all. Besides the zoo it self, there are many other attractions and activities to do, especially if you’re a kid. The best option to scape the queue is to buy the tickets on line on your phone, go directly to the entrance gate and show the QR code to the guard. Enjoy

Great experience seeing animals that are native to Peru, especially the ones in the Sierra and Selva: condors, vicunas, alpacas, variety of monkeys (including the smallest one in South America), otorongos (jaguars), other different large felines, ronsocos (capybaras), etc.
Recommend coming during weekdays when it is not as busy so you can snap better pictures of your favorite animals.
I was amazed.  I've been to several US zoos.  This one blows them away.  As an added bonus, they built the zoo around 500-2000 year old Huaca ruins.
Very interesting archeological site, surrounded by high rise apartments. Well restored and maintained, no guides and just one informational sign.
Very good and neat, have security close to the building. It was very close to Avenida la marina, super market  tottus, metro.
Small. Very mych restored. But good explanations on signboards in spanish only.
Poli
Hermsoo
I loved it a lot. Because of the quarantine, I couldn't enjoy it much, but I had a great time. It improved a lot.

Beautiful ocean views, beautiful sunsets.
Bringing your own vehicle is ideal for families. The day I went, there were children flying kites; it was great to see their smiles.
It's a quiet place where you can go for a moment to look at the sea and relax for a while from your car, on a bike, or on foot 😉
Good place to walk!!!
Pedestrian paths, cycle paths, organized lanes and traffic lights, in the midst of tree plantation work, with green areas, cleanliness must be better maintained......
It looks like it was great on its time, now it needs maintenance, it's forgotten, neglected.

Excellent place to visit and take photos and learn a little more about the history of Peru 🇵🇪🇵🇪

Paseo de Aguas is a charming promenade in Lima, offering a tranquil escape amidst the city's bustle. Located near the historic center, it features lush greenery, decorative fountains, and sculptures, making it a pleasant spot for a leisurely walk. The area is rich in history, with nearby colonial-era architecture adding to its charm. Often visited by locals and tourists alike, Paseo de Aguas is a peaceful haven for relaxation and photography. The clean, well-kept surroundings, combined with its serene ambiance, make it an ideal place to enjoy a quiet moment while exploring Lima's cultural landscape.
Horrible place food make me sick
Not in the best of neighborhoods, but it's a beautiful place with a beautiful historic love story behind it.
Dangerous area. Too bad as arch is quite beautiful with a small park next to it. Don’t go by yourself
It was not functional when I visited. Needs to be repainted. Not in the best of neighborhoods.
Not a must visit place by any stretch of the imagination but if you live in Lima and wanna visit different parks, this is certainly an option. Clean park with lots of families enjoying their time.
The best place.
This place was under renovation when we visited on Aug 2023; would not recommend it; just a walk through park and not much else here.
Beautiful place to go with friends or family
Good to go!
ok
A wonderful visit, warm welcome, and good information about the history of the place and its ongoing projects.
Nice place, just needs the state to invest money to rebuild it.
It lacks tourist orientation, the area is unsafe

The place is a tourist attraction, the house where Perricholi lived with her lover, Viceroy Amat; however, the place is somewhat dangerous for outsiders, due to the many villas and alleys surrounding the entrances, where a number of young people gather, who engage in snatching and drug use. Not all of them, however, lack security, despite the fact that the municipality built a security module that never worked, regrettable but true.
The hike up to here was rough but the view was worth it. The also have a restroom and vendors nearby which was great. Definitely will be back when I’m in Lima again.

San Cristóbal Hill is a very beautiful place, with stunning views of the city and an ideal atmosphere for having a good time. It's an excellent spot for activities like kite flying 🪁 and also has an exciting history that makes it even more interesting to explore.

However, there are aspects that could be improved. The place looks quite littered and somewhat untidy, which detracts from its appeal. I also noticed a lack of cleanliness and poor security, something that would be important to improve to make the experience much more enjoyable for visitors.

Despite this, I really liked it for its views and the cultural value it represents. With a little more care and organization, San Cristóbal Hill could be an even more special destination for everyone. 🌄✨

We went up on a Thursday night with a group of cyclists. For my first time, I did find the climb quite challenging, so you have to go slowly and maybe get off and push your bike in some cases. It's always recommended to go in a group. You can see it from the top, and while you're climbing, it's spectacular. Once you're at the top, there are stalls where you can buy snacks. It's much busier on weekends. Always be careful of the cars and motorcycles going up and down.

It is a custom to visit especially during Easter, approximately 1 hour 20 minutes to go up, there is a lack of bins to deposit garbage and education not to throw garbage on the floor. San Cristóbal Hill is a hill located between the districts of Rímac and San Juan de Lurigancho, it is a religious pilgrimage destination.  Formerly considered Apu, a deity of pre-Hispanic cultures and populations, a place of worship and Inca worship in the Rimac Valley by the Incas, it was baptized with its current name by the Spanish conquistador Francisco Pizarro in 1535.

Excellent panoramic view of the city, but to get there you must use your own vehicle since there are no or few taxis or motorcycle taxis. This is important when considering how to get there and how to leave.

It is one of the most historically significant sites in the city of Lima. It has been restored and improved through various interventions and renovations. This has helped halt the deterioration seen in the past, and has led many visitors to better understand what can be done with historical sites in Lima and Peru in general.
Nice

The Barefoot Museum in Rímac has its charm. It is a quiet place, with beautiful colonial architecture and several interesting spaces, many paintings and prayer environments. The guided tour helps a lot to understand the history of the convent and the life of the friars.

I recommend that you always get around in the morning for safety, and walk with a guide if you are not a local. Also get to the door by taxi, since I don't know if there are public buses that leave you in front of the museum or similar.

Muy interesante y bonito.
Muy cuidado.
Con mucha historia, me encantó

Excellent choice of museum, full of art and tradition.
10 points for Damaris, who was our guide throughout the museum, explaining everything in detail and, above all, providing insight into what was on display in each hall.
I will definitely return.

A colonial gem in Rímac. A historic convent dating back to 1595, it is now a museum showcasing a priceless collection of religious art, as well as the entire history of the Franciscan congregation in Peru. It truly is a place worth visiting.
Very nice spot with plants, animals, sweet soft breeze and oversight.
Winter is not the time..

It's an inspiring experience. Learning about the story of a migrant woman who started a recovery project in a deserted valley restores hope. They serve lunch and have a bar.
They could improve the appearance of the entrance and the service of the bar staff a little. Small details that would make the experience more personal.
Nice experience, it has its appeal although they could improve it,
It is located on the left side of the San Martín station on Line 1 of the Lima metro.
Cute. I like.

Recreational and enjoyable site for all with comfortable courts and recreational areas for enjoyment

It is a nice place and very nice to spend with the family. I do not put 5 because it lacks some improvement but the place is wonderful.

Good tourist and ecological city, I loved it.

I live in Cieneguilla, and under the grotesque current mayor, I've seen the ecological quality change to oncological quality with the increase in invasions and land trafficking right in front of the guy. It's truly tragic that the authorities turn a blind eye to this calculated destruction, thus becoming complicit. However, it's still an excellent place to visit on the weekends.
Beautiful place to entertain the little ones next to you, a complete and diverse park for different ages. They even have a pool to cool off in a nice and hot place. I highly recommend it.
It is a place where you find very good service, fair prices and a wide variety of top quality products.
It's calm super relaxed
It is very spacious, it has a sports slab, it has decent maintenance of green areas, but the park needs a remodel since it has dirt roads and makes it look very rustic.

This is a quick but fun stop. If you have 60 minutes to kill in San Isidro and want to see a little history, go here. Entry fee was 5 soles per person in August 2025.
The site is in a lovely residential part of San Isidro.

This is a relatively small pre-Incan site in Lima.  It is worth visiting if you are in the neighborhood, but there are better pyramid sites to see in Lima.  You can walk up the pyramid, and there are decent views.  The museum itself was a bit underwhelming. Still, it is an impressive piece of history in the middle of a modern city, so see it if you are nearby.
Interesting to visit although there is a limited amount of things to see

I walked here with a broken leg, and when I got here, they said the credit card machine was broken, and we cannot get in without cash. We just arrived to Peru and did not have it, and even though it's 5 soles, they would not help us. We had to take an Uber to our hotel and could not get in. Crutches and all, denied entry. We understand we aren't entitled, I get it...but a little heartless. Bad start to Peru.

Not an expensive visit but with the amount of info provided from just the signs (in English and Spanish), you’ll be done in 15-30 minutes. The guy in front of me at the ticket counter didn’t read at all and was in and out in under 10 minutes. Highly recommend you walk around outside of the site as well (free/before entry gates) as the places you can go within are quite limited.

It's an nice park surrounded by busy streets.
At one side there is a secured parking lot for bikes Where they want your name and your passport number.
In the park were lots of cats chilling around the area. You have also nice cafes around the park where you get meals and drinks for fair money.
Nice place to walk maybe do some picnic ...Starbucks and San Antonio...

Parque Combate de Abtao is a historic park in the heart of Lima, commemorating the Battle of Abtao, a significant naval victory in Peru’s war of independence. The park features a monument dedicated to the battle, along with sculptures and plaques that highlight this key moment in Peruvian history. It offers a peaceful environment with green spaces, making it a popular spot for locals to relax, walk, and socialize. The park’s central location in the Jesús María district also adds to its accessibility, providing a pleasant blend of history, culture, and nature for both residents and visitors to enjoy.
The park is well preserved. It have a beautiful playground. Around it, there are some restaurants and clothing stores.
Nice park to go for a stroll or maybe pick up a sandwich in a nearby restaurant and have a one person picnic
Very tranquil place to relax & see the fish & turtles. Lots of police presence too which helped to make the park feel safe.
Maybe the biggest park in San Isidro district, open to everyone. With benches and fountains a nice place to relax and ease your mind.
One of the best place that I visit this year!
One of the most beautiful Parks in Lima 💜, and also between all of the olive trees you can find the oldest one, planted by Saint Martín de Porres, And which dates from 1637 😱

Cute pond with lots of koi roiling around and lovely turtles. But the water is bright green meaning there is too much nutrient load from all the animals excrement and insufficient uptake by plants to filter out the abundance. Aeration is also helpful in keeping the water fresher. But I enjoyed all the flower planting in the middle of the pond islands.

Huaca Pucllana: 4000-year-old pyramid, check. Boring guide who puts you to sleep, check. If you're gonna make me walk on ancient genius pyramid, at least make the tour entertaining. Suggestion: skip the guide and hit up the Larco Museum first. Learn more over there Trust me, you'll be way more impressed when you finally get to the real education. And honestly, just read the Wikipedia page, you'll learn more.
Need tour guide and takes about one hour.

2000+ years of history packed into the center of Miraflores. A must see when visiting Lima to acquire some of the history and respect for previous civilization. The adobe architecture is incredible as millions of bricks were assembled into the pyramid that took hundreds of years to assemble. Get to see some of the agriculture and animals of Peru - guinea pigs and alpacas.

The museum offers some insight, but the real value is the guided tours that leave every 30 minutes and are offered in both English and Spanish. Cost of entry is S/ 15, about $4 (includes the tour)

This is such a fun treasure in the city! It's a quick 45-60 min tour talking about the Lima culture that predates the Inca civilization. It's not an intense hike, but closed toed shoes and pants are a good idea just because of the dust. We went on an overcast day and it was perfect, I can see it getting super hot on a sunny day, there is no shade.

We visited in the morning and it was the perfect time to go. It’s so cool to see this massive ancient site right in the middle of modern Lima and it was literally behind our hotel.

They offer tours in both English and Spanish, and it’s included in the ticket price. Yours are required to visit. Our guide did a great job explaining the history and how the structure was used by the Lima culture over 1,500 years ago. The pyramid made of adobe bricks is super impressive up close!

Huaca Pucllana is a fascinating archaeological site right in the heart of Lima. The guided tour brings the history of this ancient adobe pyramid to life, explaining its importance to the Lima culture long before the Incas. It’s incredible to see such a well-preserved piece of history surrounded by the modern city. A positive and worthwhile experience for anyone interested in Peru’s rich past. You have to have a guide with you to enter. This is part of the admission fee.

The Malecón in Miraflores is one of the most beautiful spots to experience in Lima, especially in the morning. Walking along the cliffs with the Pacific Ocean stretching endlessly in front of you is truly breathtaking. The fresh morning breeze, the sound of the waves crashing against the rocks, and the calm atmosphere make it a perfect place to start the day. The parks along the Malecón are well-maintained with colorful flowers, palm trees, and jogging or cycling tracks where you can see locals staying active. In the early hours, it feels peaceful and less crowded, giving you uninterrupted views of the ocean and the sunrise glow reflecting over the water. The scenic beauty, combined with the clean pathways and green spaces, makes the Malecón a must-visit not just for tourists but also for anyone who loves nature and tranquility.
Nice place for a leisure walk.  Beautiful sunset
A beautiful walk with perfectly landscaped surroundings and stunning ocean views.  An old lighthouse, monuments, artwork, a pagoda on a cliff.  Great exercise with an ocean breeze!  Not to be missed.
Such a beautiful place for a walk to catch the sunset. Lots of areas to sit and green space for the dogs and kids to play or to picnic.
A nice walk to take in the beautiful coastal views of Lima
This is a nice little park along the walkway linking many other parks.  It is a good place to sit down and have a rest.  There is a small cafe nearby to grab a coffee or soft drink.

Lovely park with that big statue and amazing views of the ocean. The tile work is adorable too. The park area looks clean  and safe. We took a lot of pictures here and sat down and enjoyed the breeze. There were a lot of people at the time we went.

Nothing special. Some writings on the walls are vulgar, which I did not find romantic or poetic. It's an area full of people who want to sell you souvenirs, which gets a bit annoying given the concentration of sellers.
Love park is great place to take a break and go for a walk to get good energy and positive vibe!!
I love this park. First time in Lima June 2025, sunny day, amazing sunset, nice people good vibes.
Didn't get to see the lights the last time since it was too early, but I was able to enjoy it today.

I decided to take a leisurely walk all the water and this was a great way to spend it. There is a quite lengthy path from Barranco down to Miraflores. It appears to be a series of parks where you’ll see a mix of things as you progress through the various sections.

Some kids will be playing sports, little family picnics, people just sunbathing/reading. In some areas, you’ll see some snacks for sale or companies selling parasailing adventures.
The sunsets here are truly spectacular, offering breathtaking views year-round, whether it's the warm glow of summer or the crisp chill of winter

A beautiful lush green park near the beach. Lots of events are organized here, I attended world yoga day event there organized by municipalidad de Miraflores. A perfect place for doing yoga and other exercises. This park allows pets also. Must visit.

Beautiful park that even some Lima natives don’t even know about! Nazca line on a budget! I strongly suggest walking along the entire waterfront along the many parks (up on the cliffs, not the beach which is a separate walk).

Beautiful and lively park in the heart of Miraflores. The place is very well maintained, clean, and always full of energy. The unique highlight is the large number of friendly cats roaming around, which makes the park quite special. In the evenings, you can enjoy street performances, small fairs, and local food stalls. It’s surrounded by restaurants, cafes, and shops, so it’s a perfect spot to relax or take a break while exploring the city. A must-visit when in Lima, especially if you love cats and vibrant local culture.

I'm utterly smitten! This cat park is an absolute haven! The moment I stepped in, I was surrounded by bundles of fur and affection. Each little ball of fluff had its own unique personality, and I couldn't get enough of their adorable snuggles and purrs. I'm already planning my next visit - 10/10 would recommend to all cat lovers out there! If you're a cat person like me, you'll fall head over heels for this place!

The park was very active/ crowded as it was a Sunday. We loved seeing the colorful art being sold by artists. The cat stalls, karaoke being sung by Asian artists, the many interesting stalls. The place has a vibrant, joyful atmosphere.

Absolutely one of the highlights of Lima, a park full of cats!
With little cat hotels around the park to house them, lovely volunteers who show up to feed the cats daily, and some lovely snuggles if you just quietly sit on the grass and wait. There’s always a lap cat waiting for a cuddle.

There are a lot of cats in this park, most of them strays. People have built small houses for them to live in. But I wonder what these cats are like during the winter or rainy season when it rains heavily. Many tourists come to take pictures with the cats. I find them cute but also feel sorry for them.

This is a nice place to walk and view the coastline and paragliders in good weather.  There are numerous parks along this stretch, with tennis and pickleball courts available.  The lighthouse itself is historical and interesting.
Nice walk along the sea beach. Great view If the weather is sunny.
Beautiful areas to walk down the coast line of Lima.

We visited El Faro (the marine lighthouse) during our recent trip to Peru. It’s located in Miraflores, just two blocks from where I went to school! The area is beautiful, with manicured landscaping and amazing ocean views. Such a nice spot to take a walk, relax, or snap a great picture like this one! Definitely recommend stopping by if you’re in the area.
Beautiful spot to watch the surf and paragliders.
It has a small playground area, perfect for the little ones to have some fun. Ocean views are amazing.

The park is a historical landmark named after Alfredo Salazar Southwell, a young aviator of the Peruvian Air Force hailed as a national hero 🇵🇪🇵🇪🇵🇪🇵🇪🇵🇪

*** The field is the site of his plane crash in 1937. While preparing for the national celebration of José Chavez, the plane he piloted had mechanical problems that he ordered his co-pilot to parachute to safety. He flew the troubled plane out of the populated area of Lima, crashing into then an open field on the cliffs of Miraflores Borough, saving hundreds of lives at the expense of his own!

The park was built by Lima City in 1953 to honor Salazar Southwell’s ultimate sacrifice.

Today, the park is a vibrant center of human activity of modern Lima. It is Central Miraflores itself, the focal point of the Malecón with a lovely view of the cliffs and the ocean. The park is the home of the Larcomar commercial and entertainment complex.

Beautiful park-in miraflores Peru at the edge of a Cliff overlooking the ocean.  There is a Mall located in the park with a lot of restaurants and shops. Along the walking trail of the park are small trucks and shops selling snacks. Very peaceful and serene place to visit .

Absolutely stunning location with a beautiful view! Perfect spot to unwind and relax while enjoying the mesmerizing parachutes overhead. Conveniently close to the mall, and the sea view is simply breathtaking. Highly recommended for a tranquil escape!
Beautiful clean park in the edge of a Clift overlooking the ocean. Surprisingly quiet and serene. Mall located underneath and snacks sold in small carts.
Beautiful views but parc is under construction but seems almost finished.
Large park with multiple workout stations and many benches. Relax and workout, your choice. Don’t like either? Look out to the beautiful Atlantic Ocean and coast of Lima. Great views.
Enjoyed a nice walk along the coast. No worries about safety at all.

Cool park, clean, safe. Obviously there's a few people trying to sell you stuff but they are not pushy or intrusive.
Definitely check this place out.
Has good views of the water as well chairs that has Gaudi vibes.

Great place to feel the blowing sea wind, watching the beautiful scene, the parasail flying with the birds, to feel the sea water flushing the bank. You must be here waiting to see the sunset at about 18:00 which is real beautiful.

It's fenced. It has improved compared to several years ago when it looked like an abandoned place. Now it has better maintained trees, it looks clean, everything around is fenced. But more recovery work is needed in the huaca. I wish the local authorities and the community would give it more importance and recover it as an archaeological center of which to feel part.
I recommend Punto Marisco, it's a place where they serve you the best, the food is delicious, thanks to the advisor Marco for his kind attention.

This site has not yet been fully developed.
Free to visit (you can see it, but don't step on it).
Do not climb the walls!
Very nice, small and very good distribution of spaces
It has improved quite a bit, although it is still somewhat abandoned, apart from the fact that I once saw people who were not from the ministry enter.
Ks

An archaeological site also known as Huaca Pro, or Huaca de Oro by locals, although this is not official. Located in the Los Olivos district, very close to the so-called Cerro Pro (possibly Fortaleza Pro).
Surrounded by a well-maintained park, it is unfortunately used as a bicycle ramp by children and young people. This, despite signs posted in the designated area urging people not to damage the huaca.
The best experience I’ve had! The man who owns this museum is so smart and filled with love and passion for his culture! If you are visiting Lima please take the time to visit this amazing museum!
It is an incredible place, it needs more diffusion :)
A must visit !! Really interesting
Its so pretty

The wonderful researcher Enrique Niquin has worked a lifetime, recovering the legacy of the COL-LIS - Collique, with humility but determination. The museum is a place that pays tribute to this ancient people, to our roots, and to the nobility of someone as brilliant as Niquin! Visit it soon!

A pre-Hispanic structure located between the districts of Carabayllo and Comas consists of almost three blocks of walls forming the shape of an L.
The Tungasuca wall, also known as the Colli epimurales (named after the Colli lordship that occupied the area), is in a state of severe deterioration due to the neglect of the district authorities.
Its structure has a wide base and a narrower upper section.
The archaeological site is partially neglected and loses its way through the nearby houses.
Entrance to the park is not too adecuate for wheelchair or baby strollers but can get through. The park has a lot of green areas to sit on grass, play, picnic and other activities.
On weekdays is not crowded. I dont like to go on saturdays and sundays. Too many people and there is  space to enjoy.
Cute animals

Lack of maintenance. Entrance fee PEN 3 for adults and PEN 1 for children

Nice park with animals, mini zoo, water events, mini farm where kids can feed animals. Also a lot of foodstores, pools, sport, and play places for kids and a lot of grass where you can relax on.
Dogs are welcome in this park on a leash and you need to clean their dirt.

By the time I visited, this site was almost abandoned; it had been victim to grave robbers and there were no caretakers. However, it now has controls. This is one of my favorite places, providing direct contact with the ancient inhabitants of the area near the sea. This is one of the oldest archaeological sites in Peru, dating back to the Late Archaic Period (3500–1800 BC).

Cool place. Only pre-scheduled weekend tours now due to covid. One of the oldest U shape civilizations in the area. I believe it is the earliest evidence of the Fanged Deity in the Lima area. Large site. The "side arms" of the U shape structures are spread further out than I anticipated.

1) Limits of Lima where Rimac Valley touches coast.
2) 1959 when realized u shape.
3) 1640 - 900 BC.
4) Bad state.
5) Mined for construction fill.
6) Many in Lima - same issues.
7) Found fresco on Main wall on pyramid.
a) Fanged deity.

Biggest (9 ha) and quite beautiful archeological site of the city, started 3500 years ago (Chavin culture, 300 km N of Lima). 3 pyramids forming a U shaped area. The highest 26 meters high one used to host 3 temples: the oldest and biggest cultic place was on top and has been destroyed especially since the 1950s, the intermediate one is protected by a roof on the northern slope (includes high relief polychrome friezes 1 500 BC). Excavations slowly going on. Ask the security guards in the central hut to walk with you because of a few agressive drug addicts squatting in some places.
I was harrassed by a few people there. Go at ur own risk

This natural viewpoint, located outside Bicentennial Park, offers a 200-meter view of the ocean. It's located on the pedestrian path next to the bike path surrounding this beautiful park. It's extremely safe and has active security guards.
Very nice, tidy and clean park. It has security and separates the cycle path from children.

This place needs to review its entry policy. Went on a weekday evening with a reservation, and was asked at the door for my name and DNI/passport number. Never been asked for my personal information at a restaurant in Peru before.

Then we walk inside and it’s almost empty. The cocktails were alright, decent. The causa limeña was a disaster. I wonder if they’re trying to be overly innovative. But what was served could not pass as a causa in my opinion

We also loved the vibe, low-lit, and luxurious. I would highly recommend this bar for a good time and excellent drinks.
Great bar to talk and to spend quality time. Tartar was delicious as well as cocktails and beer

One more representative that we can take as an example, in the district of Comas. Representative of youth, who in the name of his country offers his life, despite the pain he may face.

Two rocks existing in the place, one lower than the other, to the West and East, respectively.
The first, also called the San Agustín viewpoint, located towards the west, contains at the top a grotto with the image of San Agustín. It is reached through three lines of stairs. To date, unfortunately, the usual greenery has been neglected.
In the second, located towards the East, it is discovered and where some religious activities take place. It is taller than the other.
This place is called Mirador de San Agustín, not the San Agustín Rock, check with APUSA

Great place to see the ocean or watch the sun go down.  Apparently, the island off in the distance used to be a prison.  The alcatraz of Peru.  I was told itbis uninhabited now
Nice to hace a walkstreet and to take pictures of the sunset.

Excellent view of the ocean on a clear day
To the south you can get a glimse of the Regatas Nautical Club, to the North you can get to see La Punta at Callao ( a peninsula surrounded by the Pacific Ocean) and the San Lorenzo Island which protects the port of Callao.
Nice place. For sunset and great view of the herrafira beach and other beaches

The Mirador Catalina Recavarren in the Barranco district of Lima, Perú, offers views of Playa Barranco and the high bluffs running along the Pacific coast. In one photo a girl celebrates her quinceañera (15th birthday) at the Mirador.
We sat for a while listening to the waves and an old man playing songs on his guitar. It’s quite peaceful.
Great spot in Barranco to view the ocean. Had the pleasure of listening to local musician during our visit.

This is a nice spot to take some panoramic photos of the Lima coastline.  There are public bathrooms on the walk to the lookout point, and there is a crossing to the beach if you are interested, although the beach is not great here.

- Good place with great views
- I don’t think they have a proper beach or clean water that you can go into it but they have parks by the water. So, it’s a good area to visit in the evening by the sunset.

It's an excellent vantage point for enjoying a panoramic view of the beach. It has a relaxed, bohemian atmosphere, surrounded by urban art, trees, and street music, giving it a very special feel. It's ideal for strolling, taking photos at sunset, or simply sitting and admiring the scenery.
good view but need be careful the security
Nice view over the sea.

The view is impressive. From there, you can clearly see the ocean and the entire Miraflores area. The place seems very peaceful, with lots of people walking or enjoying the ocean view. The entire area is very green, and the park looks well-maintained.
The place is new, there's flora, and you can get around by bike or on foot. It's a great place to spend some quality time.

While walking from the bridge of sighs towards the playa we stopped here for refreshments with a vista. Excelente!  Pisco sour, cerveza, and ceviche. All were wonderful.  Great location. Friendly service, clean bathrooms, and plenty of tables with a view to the playa de barranca.

The food was pretty good. I tried anticucho for the first time and then later had ceviche. I probably wouldn't eat here again because I didn't feel it was that great. Personally I did not enjoy the service here, I found the staff to be rather inattentive and somewhat rude. The atmosphere is probably nicer during the way when you can see the vibrant trees and ocean off in the distant, but I came at night so it wasn't as nice as I'd hope.

This seafood restaurant in Barranco, Lima, blends the charm of the bohemian district with exceptional Peruvian cuisine. Set in a vibrant neighborhood known for its art and culture, the restaurant offers a cozy, stylish atmosphere that reflects the area's creative spirit. The menu features fresh, locally sourced seafood, and Peruvian traditional dishes. Each dish is crafted with care, offering a true taste of Peru’s coastal heritage. With warm, attentive service and a relaxed vibe, it's an ideal spot to enjoy a delicious meal after exploring the colorful streets of Barranco.
Really scenic spot in Barranco. Upstairs has a great view of the plaza and food was great! The chaufa was exactly what we needed after so much walking.

Waited 2 hours and our food never came, after asking what was happening they managed to get 2/5 plates on the table but the food wasn’t very good anyway (maybe because they threw it together quickly). This is probably the only 4 and under rating I’ve ever given, they didn’t seem to care when we brought our concerns to their attention so I wanted to make sure I posted this. There is a restaurant next door and saw those customers leaving happy, give them a try…
Nice viewpoint in south Barranco overlooking the beach line to north and south. The wall is covered in graffiti, which you may or may not consider adds to the atmosphere of the place.

Semi public space with the entry at the end of the street. This view point may be closed depending on the private community near by. It offers unobstructed view of the Pacific Ocean, is free to access, and just a short walk from the Barranco main plaza. It's also very quiet and only visited by locals, not a single tourist in sight.
Pretty!

This bridge itself is pretty standard - about 40 feet long with no major views to speak of. But that's not what makes it special. The real treasure is the shops surrounding it, filled with unique art designs, cool jackets, t-shirts, and bags. It's evolved beyond just a marketplace - it's now a hub for creative expression. While the restaurants nearby are okay, they're not the main draw. The real highlight is the eclectic mix of art and shopping that makes this area worth exploring.

At the Bridge of Sighs, we lucked out-the garúa had faded, leaving us with clear blue skies and a warm breeze. According to legend, if you hold your breath while walking across the bridge, your wish will be granted; and if you cross it with your lover, you are said to be blessed with eternal love. The surrounding area is delightful, with a cute park, vibrant murals, and intriguing street art that make it a perfect spot to wander and explore. Lovely area to walk around and explore or take your pup out to enjoy.

This is a beautiful tourist attraction in Barranco, Lima, Peru. Don't believe the legend that if you hold the hand of the one you love and cross the bridge while holding your breath, if you make it to the other side you will be together forever... total and utter lie 🤣🤣 Other than that there is a beautiful spot, art, food, and more to see and or eat. It also  leads down to the beach.
It’s nice area but unfortunately not as nice as I expected. Church is not lighted and that’s a pity. Would make pictures much more beautiful. Murals are nice.
Great lil artsy area and the vendors there are nice and not pushy. Would have loved to visited in the evening when the bars were open as I think there’s music then.

On a clear day, the viewpoint has splendid views of the entire city of Lima. If there were no cloud cover, you could see the sea and the islands. Of course, you have to go up in a group to avoid surprises. Motorcycle taxis charge S/ 3 per person to the soccer field called Maracaná. From the journey it is done on foot. You can also go up and down the stairs on foot, but in a group, so as not to get lost.
Lugar calmo, seguro e incrível para ver o por do sol.

Redondo Beach in Miraflores is a popular spot for surfers and vacationers. In the summer, the heat and sun are intense, so bring sunscreen. I tried a delicious raspadilla (or shaved ice) with delicious flavors at a good price (there was a special offer for two). A great place to visit any day of the week.

Miraflores Beach Viewpoint is one of the most stunning spots in Lima to enjoy the Pacific Ocean. The view from here is simply breathtaking, especially during sunrise and sunset when the sky changes colors over the waves. The cliffside location gives you a panoramic view of the coastline, surfers in the water, and the famous Costa Verde highway running below. It’s a peaceful place to walk, relax, or just sit and take in the ocean breeze. The area is well-maintained, with walking paths, benches, and nearby cafés to grab a coffee while enjoying the scenery. A must-visit viewpoint in Miraflores if you love nature, photography, or just want a calm moment with an incredible ocean view.

It is certainly a beach area with a lot of surfers, but having that said it is probably not one of the better beaches I have seen. The sand looks rocky and hard and water not so blue. If you have time on your hands come take a look but if you don’t have extra time it’s better to spend your time at other beaches in other places
Great walking space, clean, safe

Had a free half day here so decided to stroll along the coastal path. Many small parks along the path, people jogging, walking, watching the surfers down the sea and the paragliding above, lot of birds chipping among the bushes, peaceful and relaxing, can spend hours here. Fell great after a few days in high altitude area.
Great beach for surfing but it is also well if you just want to sit and enjoy the view.

This is a nice place to walk and view the coastline and paragliders in good weather.  There are numerous parks along this stretch, with tennis and pickleball courts available.  The lighthouse itself is historical and interesting.

The area is beautiful, with manicured landscaping and amazing ocean views. Such a nice spot to take a walk, relax, or snap a great picture like this one! Definitely recommend stopping by if you’re in the area.
