Small garden in honor of Chinese immigrants to Peru. A small Pagoda is in its center, surrounded by a shallow koi pond. Buddha statues here and there, and a couple plastic pandas which you can take pictures with. Oriental music plays from a speaker.

The whole thing struck me as in-authentic and a poor representation of a Chinese garden. The pond is overflowing with fish and filthy, hasn't been cleaned for ages. I pity the fish in there.

Good walk to take after a nice meal to enjoy the view, from the malecon (shore) and the breeze of the sea, it gets crowded in the evenings so go early in the afternoon so can get nice pictures of the sunset and the park, there's an area for kids to play in the upper level. Good location for a picnic with the family, just keep in mind the areas where the Chinese statues are is kind of small.

It’s was built to recognize Chinese emigres, but it probably the most poorly designed park in the Malecon. There’s nothing Chinese about it👎👎👎.

The focal point is a pergola that is a pseudo-pagoda👎👎👎…looks pretty from a distance but not quite the Buddhist nor Taoist  design.

The so-called garden is even worst. There’s a very shallow pond, more like a hand washing pool, that is so overcrowded with Koi👎. The poor creatures must be boiling in it under the heat of the equatorial sun. Over this pond a “bridge”, more like 3- foot plank, that is made of hollow plastic resin.

Then there the small buddhas, plastic pandas and other trinkets👎👎👎👎👎… it is like a child’s toy land.

From the pavement above it, is a place to watch the sunset as is any other spot on the Malecon.
Small Chinese park with panda statues, a pagoda and walking paths. Seems quite popular with the locals. Nice views from here

This was a delightful surprise while walking on the beachfront boardwalk in Miraflores. There were two wedding photographers working with clients while I was here, and it is a beautiful site for it. The statuary, pond, and plants make this a sanctuary worthy of reverence. Plus there are vast views of the ocean. Check out this gem of you are in the area.

This place has delicious food paired with lots of fun for kids. The only thing they need to improve is the opening hours since the amusement park closes somewhere at 6pm which is really when temperatures are getting comfortable. During daytime it is hot there!
Great getaway. Beautiful park with lots of activities for kids. Make a day of it, play, swim, have lunch.

fun inexpensive place to take the kids.

I can say that the experience is very satisfactory, apart from taking your children to have fun, the comfort is good thanks to the workers who also have the patience to be able to serve us 💗

They even have portable toilets free of charge.
Family friendly.

First time I've been there and I was surprised by how tidy and clean it was..✨

Every game was fun, and the wait to buy tickets and get in was quick. The games change, though. I remember there were others before, but they were still fun. Everything was very clean. Bring your kids 😄❤️👋🏾

A fun place to relax for a while. The games and prizes are good, although you need a large number of tickets to win good prizes.
I recommend visiting this place.

The roulette wheels (Big Bass Wheel, Monster Jackpot, etc.) seem to be programmed to always or almost always give out 15 tickets. Aside from that, many machines didn't give out any tickets at all.

Super bad, the games are expensive, they don't give you any explanation, if you miss going for a month they force you to fill out a form, the games are almost always empty, if your child goes in it's to get bored alone, some games are not well maintained, they look worn and dirty.

A nice, simple place for children. They can watch and care for their children because it is small. The bad thing is that it is somewhat small. It is worth highlighting the court for playing.

It has various recreational areas, good security, everything is very clean, excellent for taking the kids to play for a while.
Small, picturesque, perfect for an afternoon with your child in Surquillo.

This is one of my favorite places. It is a beautiful park and is well-maintained. Certain times of the day/evening are busier, and there are usually a lot of wedding and quinceanera photographers. It's fun to watch though -- a lot of beautiful gowns.

Parque de la Felicidad was designed to cover and protect Surco River that crosses that area. It has a biophysical water treatment plant, that includes the use of water hyacinth to extract heavy metals that are potentially present in Surco River water. Good place for an academic visit with students. It is under the administration of San Borja City Hall (Municipalidad de San Borja).
Look, I know it's a popular spot to take photos but it was absolutely trashed. The sidewalks were nasty and the "lake" is gross, it's literally green.
Lovely park with fountains, very well kept gardens and children’s climbing frames
Really beautiful park, clean and well maintained. However, a lot of people go there to take professional pictures for weddings and ceremonies that make it a little bit crowded

This place is pretty fun, but very expensive for what it is. They make your purchase socks to wear inside, and then when you take those socks off after an hour of existing there your entire foot is black anyway. If anything, provide some hazmat suits or eliminate the ridiculous amount of dust.

It's basically just a bunch of trampolines, bouncy things and a few slides.
We were invited to a kid’s bday and obviously the kids had fun in this kind of place but the personal  is not kind  at all. Besides the parking fee is so expensive. Not sure I wanna go back there.
top!

The place is ideal for children, but not so much for adults. The hygiene leaves a lot to be desired: the helmets were dirty and had a very strong smell, which was somewhat unpleasant. It would be a better experience if they incorporated activities designed for those over 18.

The worst experience was with a girl at the parking entrance, who was extremely rude and abusive. Instead of politely explaining that you can't stop the car, not even to check prices or verify entry, she became hostile and began taking photos of the vehicle without any justification. A completely unnecessary and out-of-place attitude.

Everything is dirty. The games for teens and adults (climbing) are in the same space as the children's. They take photos of the wristband constantly (when the wristband is only for hours). If you go from one room to another, they waste your time with this and with waiting for them to open a chain that separates the two main rooms of the establishment. The bathrooms are poorly painted and stink. All the synthetic grass is brown (it looks like it was once green), the floors of the climbing area are disgusting, the balls in the pools are beyond praise, and the only bumper boat I used had broken steering.

We had a wonderful day. Perfect place to spend the day with kids in Lima. We went as a family group ages from 2-17 kids/teens and 42-74 adults. Everyone had a great time with games, rides, the pools, and waterslides. We also enjoyed visiting the farm animals. We spend >6h and didn't see everything (mostly because we spend a lot of time in the waterpark).

Such a cute place to visit with the kiddos, a lot of restrictions around pools unlike waterparks in other countries, e.g no walking with shoes or must have bathing suits on before walking inside pool area and no using hot tub after 4pm on weekdays, but putting those aside definetely makes it worth going with the kids for a nice outing.
A small amusement park. They've got some animals, and you can feed them food you buy at the park, so that was nice. It's not in a good part of town though.
More than worth it!!! Only a $20 all access pass!!!! Lots of fun and big!!! The earlier you arrive the best it is to take advantage of everything there is to do in there!!!
This was a nightmare, they asking you id, even if you have kid they don’t let you bring food for them, one hour to enter, they don’t allow you anything.

I really enjoyed the experience. There are various games, such as Laser Combat, Paintball, ATVs, Zip Line, Gym, Obstacle Course, Aero Basketball, Hanging Bridges, Tagada, and Golfito. It's really comprehensive. They also sell food and have a Food&Plus Restaurant with grilled chicken and a vegan option. The downside is that there's no water in the pipes; they only release it occasionally.

Action park of more than 20,000 m2 that offer game packages whose prices vary according to the combinations chosen. The games are: Canopy, paintball, physical competition circuit, aerobasketball, snipper, suspension bridge, ATVs, minigolf, climbing among others. We had an amazing time learning about the religious significance of Pachacamac throughout the centuries. The museum was a definite highlight; well laid out, informative, and with interpretive signs in both English and Spanish, which made the experience accessible and engaging. Walking through the archaeological sanctuary was enjoyable, though it wasn’t quite as visually spectacular as some other sites in Peru. Still, the overall experience was enriching and well worth the visit for those interested in pre-Columbian history and ancient Andean spirituality.

This sanctuary and museum is located around 1 hour from miraflores . I was impressed by the museum that although it is smaller you will enjoy learning about the culture then it has a restaurant clean restrooms and the huacas you can go by car or walk it will take 1 h or less depending on your own time and the general price is 15 soles less than 6 dollars

I was blown away by the scale and significance of Pachacamac. The archaeological sanctuary is expansive, with sweeping desert landscapes, coastal views, and remarkably well-preserved structures that speak to centuries of continuous occupation and worship. Walking among the ruins—especially the Temple of the Sun and the Painted Temple—you really feel the spiritual and historical weight of the site.

The on-site museum is excellent: modern, informative, and well-curated, with artefacts that add depth and context to what you see outside. Exhibits are displayed beautifully, and the signage (in both Spanish and English) helps paint a vivid picture of the cultures that once thrived here.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in Peru’s pre-Hispanic history. Come early, wear a hat, and give yourself time to explore—it’s absolutely worth it.

Super cool to see the history here and learn about the different cultures that developed it over the millennia. I definitely suggest taking the orange route - walking through the streets and getting the tour guide as well. Totally worth it! Cabify was like 59 soles for each way from Miraflores Lima (about an hour with traffic each way tho). There wasn’t anyone there when we went.

Pachachamac has a history dating back to 200 BC and it has influences from Lima, Wari, Ychma and Incas culture. It used to be a pilgrimage centre and Pachacamac was a feared god with power to cause earthquakes. The current site has a museum and the excavations from the  structures built centuries ago - Sun Temple, Pachacamac, Acllawasi. During Inca rule (the last kingdom before Spanish Colonialisation), many people user to visit this site as a pilgrimage and many pyramids were built here. Sun Temple is supposed to have quite an ideal location based on planets and it faces the sea. There was a school built for girls called Acllawasi where they were taught day to day routine work. The excavation work is still in progress here. Entry ticket is 15 Soles for regular route and 20 Soles for special route. It was great knowing about this much ancient history. If you are a history buff, then this site is a must visit in your Lima it itinerary. Guided tours are available in both Spanish and English and cost 50 Soles.

Biggest (9 ha) and quite beautiful archeological site of the city, started 3500 years ago (Chavin culture, 300 km N of Lima). 3 pyramids forming a U shaped area. The highest 26 meters high one used to host 3 temples: the oldest and biggest cultic place was on top and has been destroyed especially since the 1950s, the intermediate one is protected by a roof on the northern slope (includes high relief polychrome friezes 1 500 BC). Excavations slowly going on. Ask the security guards in the central hut to walk with you because of a few agressive drug addicts squatting in some places.

Huaca La Florida is an archaeological site located in the Rímac valley, on the central coast of Peru (Lima). It belongs to the formative period, dating back to 1700 BC. C. It contains the remains of an architectural complex with a “U”-shaped plan, being the most representative of this style, as well as one of the oldest.

In Peru, "huaca" (word of Quechua origin) is usually referred to a place that preserves the remains of some Inca or pre-Inca population, or the remains of sacred constructions. The Huaca La Merced is a small archaeological monument restored and recovered by a team led by archaeologists Cecilia Camargo and Pedro Caycho with architect Mirna Soto.

This huaca belonged to the Ichma culture and its structures were made with river stones and mud bricks forming a pyramid with ramps and staircases.

Prior to its restoration, the place was looted by "huaqueros", unscrupulous people who violate these places for profit, although, in spite of this, it was possible to find remains of vessels, textiles, bones, instruments, mollusk shells, spondylus and also a funerary bundle in excellent condition.

Despite announcements and promises to offer the huaca for the visit of those interested in history, culture, architecture and other branches of science, they have not even built the promised small Site Museum nor constructed the 11 cabinets for research and other purposes. They do not open the place at least once a month to offer a guided tour, and we are left to see it only behind a metal mesh ...

Huaca Pucllana: 4000-year-old pyramid, check. Boring guide who puts you to sleep, check. If you're gonna make me walk on ancient genius pyramid, at least make the tour entertaining. 2000+ years of history packed into the center of Miraflores. A must see when visiting Lima to acquire some of the history and respect for previous civilization. The adobe architecture is incredible as millions of bricks were assembled into the pyramid that took hundreds of years to assemble. Get to see some of the agriculture and animals of Peru - guinea pigs and alpacas.

The museum offers some insight, but the real value is the guided tours that leave every 30 minutes and are offered in both English and Spanish. Cost of entry is S/ 15, about $4 (includes the tour)

This is such a fun treasure in the city! It's a quick 45-60 min tour talking about the Lima culture that predates the Inca civilization. It's not an intense hike, but closed toed shoes and pants are a good idea just because of the dust. We went on an overcast day and it was perfect, I can see it getting super hot on a sunny day, there is no shade.

We visited in the morning and it was the perfect time to go. It’s so cool to see this massive ancient site right in the middle of modern Lima and it was literally behind our hotel.

They offer tours in both English and Spanish, and it’s included in the ticket price. Yours are required to visit. Our guide did a great job explaining the history and how the structure was used by the Lima culture over 1,500 years ago. The pyramid made of adobe bricks is super impressive up close!

Huaca Pucllana is a fascinating archaeological site right in the heart of Lima. The guided tour brings the history of this ancient adobe pyramid to life, explaining its importance to the Lima culture long before the Incas. It’s incredible to see such a well-preserved piece of history surrounded by the modern city. A positive and worthwhile experience for anyone interested in Peru’s rich past. You have to have a guide with you to enter. This is part of the admission fee.

A pre-Hispanic structure located between the districts of Carabayllo and Comas consists of almost three blocks of walls forming the shape of an L.
The Tungasuca wall, also known as the Colli epimurales (named after the Colli lordship that occupied the area), is in a state of severe deterioration due to the neglect of the district authorities.
Its structure has a wide base and a narrower upper section.
The archaeological site is partially neglected and loses its way through the nearby houses.
Clean but small and closed.
my family has taken care of this place since I can remember It always made my summer in Peru fun and played soccer with el puma who is my uncle

To tell the truth, it is the most ridiculous and shapeless huaca I have ever seen in my life and to top it off, Buenavista doesn't have a 24-hour huaca, the people passing by don't know what a guaca is. If it isn't for that filthy sign that says it's a huaca called culebra... I'm very sorry but that's my honest opinion.

One of the surviving archaeological sites of the Maranga Complex. The Lima municipality commissioned the restoration of this site, in addition to other huacas. It's a shame that the current mayor's administration doesn't give importance to cultural issues. It needs research.
This huaca is too small, if they wanted to rescue some culture they would have preserved a larger area, a building would be better there.

Sierra and Mining
Although not widely visited, the Sierra area near Huaca Tres Palos preserves the charm of the riches its mountains provide. Thanks to the efforts of the mining sector, a mineshaft has been recreated, allowing visitors to see firsthand how a mine is exploited in the Peruvian Andes. In addition, a well-built model shows what an open-pit mine is like, a truly unique experience for those who haven't had the good fortune to experience it firsthand.
Huaca Tres Palos, ceremonial center of the Yshma culture...
Interesting, I had not realized that within the Parque de las Leyendas there were so many Huacas and they are all recovered and very well maintained.

Huaca San Pedro is one of the many that exist in the Chorrillos district. This huaca belonged to the Ychsma culture...currently, it's completely neglected and used as a garbage dump by local residents. Needless to say, it serves as a gathering point for drug users and the underclass.
Neglected by the Ministry of Culture
It's an archaeological site, but now it's full of garbage and solid waste. They should do something to restore it...
They should enclose the huaca with bars, in front there is a house with a dog named Toby.

Virrenial Aqueduct "San Juan Grande" in the name of the Hacienda that formerly provided water, acceptable state of conservation, declared Heritage of Peru through R.S 2900-72 ED.

To be a historical piece not only of Chorrillos. If not also from Lima. It is in a state of considerable neglect and abandonment. However, it remains standing and shows the greatness of ancient engineering. It is a design based on Roman aqueducts. It is worth it to be restored and cared for so it can be displayed for future generations.
It is a shame that the INC has completely abandoned it

Beautiful, almost 7,000 years old, it protected the Paradise Citadel. It's located on Uranio Avenue, bordered to the west by Néstor Gambeta Avenue and to the east by Naranjal Avenue. Today, it's suffering from an invasion of garbage; we must do something about it.
Interesting archaeological site.
The landscape is beautiful, the track is pathetic and has been turned into a dump. The regional government should keep it clean as it is a cultural heritage site.
It is good to have cultural heritage, however it would be better if they cleaned it. The surroundings are full of garbage.
Good to go out to a place close to nature, but very dirty. I wish they would clean it and not throw garbage. Very neglected.

Cool place. Only pre-scheduled weekend tours now due to covid. One of the oldest U shape civilizations in the area. I believe it is the earliest evidence of the Fanged Deity in the Lima area. Large site. The "side arms" of the U shape structures are spread further out than I anticipated.

1) Limits of Lima where Rimac Valley touches coast.
2) 1959 when realized u shape.
3) 1640 - 900 BC.
4) Bad state.
5) Mined for construction fill.
6) Many in Lima - same issues.
7) Found fresco on Main wall on pyramid.
a) Fanged deity.

Biggest (9 ha) and quite beautiful archeological site of the city, started 3500 years ago (Chavin culture, 300 km N of Lima). 3 pyramids forming a U shaped area. The highest 26 meters high one used to host 3 temples: the oldest and biggest cultic place was on top and has been destroyed especially since the 1950s, the intermediate one is protected by a roof on the northern slope (includes high relief polychrome friezes 1 500 BC). Excavations slowly going on. Ask the security guards in the central hut to walk with you because of a few agressive drug addicts squatting in some places.
I was harrassed by a few people there. Go at ur own risk
Great

A nice walk with a good view from above of the surrounding area of La Molina. Plenty more archaeological discoveries to be made!
This is a place to bring your children and also to visit the archeological site called "Huaca" a huge park with a soccer and basketball court.
One of de best places to visit when in Lima, 5 star restaurant and ancient peruvian history.

It's a place of reflection and remembrance. Each stone represents a missing person whose family members can visit and honor. We must never allow tragic events to happen again in our country. That's what we must work and live for.

The Crying Eye is a monument to the victims of the internal war in Peru during the 1980s and 1990s. It's located within Campo de Marte. It's a small circular plaza with concentric circles forming labyrinthine paths separated by stones on which the names of some of the victims are written. I don't know the history of this place very well; I know that it could be, like almost any topic related to the era of terrorism, sanctified, used to separate us as Peruvians, and therefore a source of controversy.
The biggest problem with this space is that it's closed; it's not a place that welcomes people who pass by. As a place that commemorates and remembers difficult times in our country, it would be important to transform it into a space for sharing, where we can truly connect. Next to this monument, they've placed a children's playground and a bar area with loud music (not as loud as the concerts that are organized from time to time at the Lawn Tennis Club across the street). A perimeter fence separates the Weeping Eye from the rest of the park, which has gated access and scheduled times. Despite being a beautiful place, its use is primarily for ceremonial purposes.
Love the architecture of it, nice green areas around, lots of trees near by to provide fresh oxygen for that early morning run through a historic place.
The Municipal Palace is a welcoming place steeped in history, with various exhibitions open to the community where artists share their work with the public. A perfect place to visit.

It is a beautiful, well-preserved and decorated mansion that supports cultural promotion in the San Isidro District and the city of Lima. It offers art exhibitions, cultural workshops, and recitals. It is part of a cultural, ecological, and tourist circuit in El Olivar Park. It also offers an excellent café.

Located in the heart of Olivar, next to the small lagoon, it's a small but spectacular space for promoting art in San Isidro.

It has a permanent art exhibition, and on the second floor, painting and music teaching spaces.

Living near the San Isidro Cultural Center was one of the best experiences of living in Lima.
On this visit for the bicentennial of Peru, the municipality of San Isidro exhibits paintings of famous people of Peru, heroes of independence, as well as all the mayors.
Nice place.
The best experience I’ve had! The man who owns this museum is so smart and filled with love and passion for his culture! If you are visiting Lima please take the time to visit this amazing museum!
It is an incredible place, it needs more diffusion :)

The wonderful researcher Enrique Niquin has worked a lifetime, recovering the legacy of the COL-LIS - Collique, with humility but determination. The museum is a place that pays tribute to this ancient people, to our roots, and to the nobility of someone as brilliant as Niquin! Visit it soon!

Collique Fortress: One of the largest archaeological sites in the Comas district, covering an entire hilltop, on which the Collique Lordship was established (belonging to the Late Intermediate Period, according to J. Rowe's classification).
This lordship developed a fortress with several walls surrounding the entire hilltop, thus creating a defensive zone that was difficult to defeat.
It fell under the influence of the Cusco expansion that would constitute the future Tahuantinsuyu.

Currently, this archaeological site is neglected and is a dangerous area to visit without prior preventive measures. We must first ensure that no one is in the ruined rooms in the administrative zone (in the flat area, halfway up the hill).
Access can be gained from Tupac Amaru Avenue, although we reiterate the need for caution.
YOU SHOULD ALSO SUPPORT THE LORD OF THE COLLIQ TO BECOME FAMOUS
Very beautiful with the views from that hill.

The view of this archaeological site could be improved by removing the tents facing the road. Walls forming ramps can be seen, and there may be a platform at the top. The view is external; there are no tourist services, but there is a guide and an orientation panel. A panel could be placed with the site's age, name, pre-Hispanic cultural group, etc.

Oval mound of pre-Hispanic origin that has an access ramp to the upper area, as well as side walls still visible. On the top you can see the foundations and floors of the old Casa Hacienda Chacra Cerro. It is located in front of the Huaca Chacra Cerro II. Both sites were built and used as a single structure, however over time they ended up divided by the Chillón - Trapiche highway.

The showman, the orchestra, the dancers, the waitress, everyone here do everything to offer a special night with traditional music and food. Thay also helped me to celebrate a special birthday.

The best place in Lima to see a great variety of traditional dances from Peru, great place where you can enjoy, dance eat and drink. The showman is the best part, he is very entertaining and fun. I’ve been several times and always is so much fun. I’ll definitely will come back.

We had a great time here. The atmosphere was great and everyone was enjoying the performances. Very talented crew and friendly staff. There was a good variety of performances and the main host was hilarious! The food and drinks were good too. Everyone was encouraged to get up and dance on the stage.

The Ministerio de Cultura (Ministry of Culture) in Lima, Peru, is the government body responsible for promoting and preserving the country’s cultural heritage, arts, and traditions. Located in the capital, the ministry oversees the protection of historical monuments, indigenous cultures, and artistic expressions. It also organizes cultural events, exhibitions, and educational programs. The Ministry plays a key role in fostering cultural development and preserving Peru’s rich history, including its ancient civilizations like the Inca.

Very nice museum, spacious with art to buy and art on exhibition.

The Cafe Concierto next door is beautifully designed and has some beautiful musical events from time to time.
Excellent place for holding art exhibitions and conferences. Spacious and beautiful. Easy to reach by public transport. Highly recommended.

Great space
Awesome snack bar with a phenomenal chicken salad sandwich.

This office is located within the Ministry of Culture. Entrance is only permitted and the office is open during limited hours. It is recommended to enter before 4 p.m. through the Javier Prado door, then through the El Comercio street door.

It's fenced. It has improved compared to several years ago when it looked like an abandoned place. Now it has better maintained trees, it looks clean, everything around is fenced. But more recovery work is needed in the huaca. I wish the local authorities and the community would give it more importance and recover it as an archaeological center of which to feel part.

The bulding is not holding their main collection yet, but they have temporary exhibits. From June to December 2024 they are showing a wonderful exhibit of traditonal or "folk art" with extraordinary pieces from different parts of Perú. Pieces from well know masters of their craft, from the 20th and 21st century, with roots in milenial craft traditions. Highly recomended. Free entrance and free parking. A great addition to your Pachacamac Archeological site visit.

The future building of the national museum of Peru. Currently it is not fully operational, there are some few temporal exhibitions. They also show the 5 floor building (3 underground) and the roof as part of the visit. According to the guide, they are partially open so they can evaluate routes, capacity, interaction with public and private transportation and things like that. You can visit by free (but soon, they will start selling tickets) and arrive there by taxi, bus and waking and also in your car (they offer parking slots). Don’t forget to schedule your visit and show your covid vaccination card.
A fantastic architectural design, ready to expose the rich culture of Peru. Very friendly guides.

Well worth the visit. 1h to 2h to visit. Beautiful view across the landscape.

Best done with a local tour guide who can explain the historical relevance and facilitate you through the museum and artefacts. The site itself is spread out so if you do not prefer to spend a lot of time the tour guide with a car would save you a lot of time. Al in all a good history site to visit.
This site is where the oracle gave readings. A temple has some of the original red paint intact. There is a restored piece of the 5000 mile long Inka road. A must see.
Spectacular

We had an amazing time learning about the religious significance of Pachacamac throughout the centuries. The museum was a definite highlight; well laid out, informative, and with interpretive signs in both English and Spanish, which made the experience accessible and engaging. Walking through the archaeological sanctuary was enjoyable, though it wasn’t quite as visually spectacular as some other sites in Peru. Still, the overall experience was enriching and well worth the visit for those interested in pre-Columbian history and ancient Andean spirituality.

This sanctuary and museum is located around 1 hour from miraflores . I was impressed by the museum that although it is smaller you will enjoy learning about the culture then it has a restaurant clean restrooms and the huacas you can go by car or walk it will take 1 h or less depending on your own time and the general price is 15 soles less than 6 dollars

I was blown away by the scale and significance of Pachacamac. The archaeological sanctuary is expansive, with sweeping desert landscapes, coastal views, and remarkably well-preserved structures that speak to centuries of continuous occupation and worship. Walking among the ruins—especially the Temple of the Sun and the Painted Temple—you really feel the spiritual and historical weight of the site.

The on-site museum is excellent: modern, informative, and well-curated, with artefacts that add depth and context to what you see outside. Exhibits are displayed beautifully, and the signage (in both Spanish and English) helps paint a vivid picture of the cultures that once thrived here.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in Peru’s pre-Hispanic history. Come early, wear a hat, and give yourself time to explore—it’s absolutely worth it.

Super cool to see the history here and learn about the different cultures that developed it over the millennia. I definitely suggest taking the orange route - walking through the streets and getting the tour guide as well. Totally worth it! Cabify was like 59 soles for each way from Miraflores Lima (about an hour with traffic each way tho). There wasn’t anyone there when we went.

Pachachamac has a history dating back to 200 BC and it has influences from Lima, Wari, Ychma and Incas culture. It used to be a pilgrimage centre and Pachacamac was a feared god with power to cause earthquakes. The current site has a museum and the excavations from the  structures built centuries ago - Sun Temple, Pachacamac, Acllawasi. During Inca rule (the last kingdom before Spanish Colonialisation), many people user to visit this site as a pilgrimage and many pyramids were built here. Sun Temple is supposed to have quite an ideal location based on planets and it faces the sea. There was a school built for girls called Acllawasi where they were taught day to day routine work. The excavation work is still in progress here. Entry ticket is 15 Soles for regular route and 20 Soles for special route. It was great knowing about this much ancient history. If you are a history buff, then this site is a must visit in your Lima it itinerary. Guided tours are available in both Spanish and English and cost 50 Soles.
Neighborhood near the Los Sureños post (maternity ward). Very safe and beautiful, near here you can see the Huaca Tambo Inga, highly recommended to come here 🦔.
It's my neighborhood, very quiet and tidy ☺☺ Its main attraction is the HUACA TAMBO Inga that we have here. 😁

An interesting place at the edge of the city. We hope that with the Puerto Cultura project, this space can be restored to serve as a memorial for its citizens. It's one of the few huacas in the area that can be restored.

It's a very attractive and cultural complex. It's a shame people don't know how to appreciate our heritage. They should do something to continue preserving places like this in our country.

I'm delighted with how they support the literary events and will be back for another presentation soon. The selection of books you can read while waiting for the show to begin is varied, and there's a children's section so the little ones can read too.
Its library is spacious, quiet, and comfortable. You can go in now to browse texts or use your own materials. The staff is very friendly. Highly recommended.

A comfortable and free place for neighbors to study, read, work with a variety of books at hand, computers with Internet, toilet service, armchairs, tables and silence. Requires obtaining the license for a reasonable price and being warm in winter
It's a good place to promote culture, but it still needs a long way to go to become a great place. It has a lot of potential. They should tap into it more.

It’s a great little park on Av. Sucre. Next to the best pizza in Lima. I wouldn’t make a special trip to come and see the cross, but would combine it with a visit to the archeological museum and Plaza Bolivar.

The cross is where the park gets its name. It dates to 1579 and was where pilgrims and travellers would come to ask for safe passage across Peru and around the rest of the Americas.

This monumental cross, erected in 1579 by Catholic missionaries, stands as a historical landmark. Travelers would stop here to pray for protection on their journey to the port of Callao, a route that was once plagued by bandits.
Cool, and awesome history, but very tiny, kinda dirty, park.   Worth the photo op if you're in the area but not much else. Don't make a special trip.
Safe and quiet place

Nice and safe place inside the University of engeneering, entrance by main gate Nr 5. Old sulphite minerals mine. No big building works.

It looks abandoned

Huaca La Florida is an archaeological site located in the Rímac valley, on the central coast of Peru (Lima). It belongs to the formative period, dating back to 1700 BC. C. It contains the remains of an architectural complex with a “U”-shaped plan, being the most representative of this style, as well as one of the oldest.
Unfortunately, only the main part of the temple is preserved, the lower parts being used as a garbage dump without any clear path.
There's nothing but a giant hole and a bunch of stoners.

We took a bus to the flower market at the foot of the hill. Asked a policeman there how best to go up and if its safe. They suggested taxi. We took a tuk tuk. Nice ride going up through a community. Lovely view at the top. Stayed there about 20 minutes and a tuk tuk brought us back. I would have felt safe trekking down too.
Nice view, but you reach it over kind of favelas, so our uber driver was scared to leave us up there alone and waited for us go get us save back to the city center.
It’s a really nice place to enjoy the view over the city of lima👍🏻 Really special is when you go at night up there.

The view is not great but it's impressive to see the huge dimensions of Lima. The place is abandoned since there are no tourist buses going up there anymore. You can get a Taxi or Uber to bring you up. Make sure that the taxi is waiting, else you would have to wait a long time or descend by foot, which is not recommended as you would have to walk 30 minutes through the slums.
This is not for every tourist; it is only for those who want to see and experience all parts of the land. Be careful and cautious; Lima is mostly safe; I did not have any bad incidents…
Partly natural North-South oriented hill with a few mortar walls and remnants of agriculture on the western side. Entrance by gate 7 of the University of Engineering.

I studied at the UNI in the 1970s... I'd never heard of this huaca... why is it called Aliaga, if huacas are supposed to have names referring to indigenous ancestors? What I did learn was that the Ingenieria Urbanization was located on what used to be the Aliaga Estate.

The place is a tourist attraction, the house where Perricholi lived with her lover, Viceroy Amat; however, the place is somewhat dangerous for outsiders, due to the many villas and alleys surrounding the entrances, where a number of young people gather, who engage in snatching and drug use. Not all of them, however, lack security, despite the fact that the municipality built a security module that never worked, regrettable but true.
Compared to past administrations, the current one keeps it clean in its surroundings.

A historic place filled with great memories, next to a wonderful woman who, from a young age, raised her family through hard work, effort, and love. Her colleagues and landlords know her as Mrs. "Luz." Thank you, Mother.

The museum is definitely still being remodeled and lots of areas are not available. It was free for English speakers because very little signage in English. No English audio guide was available. There are some QR codes and English translations in the second building.  Some interesting exhibits to see but challenging without translation or audio guide. Go if you are good with just walking around and looking at exhibits or feel like translating lots on your phone.

My wife and I were happy that we decided to visit this museum this week. A few sections are not accessible, but due to the recent APEC summit, they have decided to go all in and they are currently exhibiting a few pieces they never exhibited before. There are pieces not even Peruvians have seen yet so, quality over quantity is the key. Last chance to see them too, as the museum will fully close for renovations at the end of February, and will not reopen until 2027-28.
A real Tumi, several gold and silver pieces and the best preserved textiles we've had the chance to see, are only a few of the elements that make this a worthy visit. Additionally, this museum has the real Estele Raimondi, one of the most important peruvian monoliths that still exists.
To finish, you will also get to see a well preserved colonial mansion, with original floors and a beautiful garden.

Last notes:
1. There are two entrances to the museum. Start your visit through the second one, that leads to the "Casona". This is the one that has most of the things that can be seen at the moment. Once you finish there, you can go to the main one (way less things to see atm), but mandatory if you want to see the Estele Raimondi.
2. Most of the texts are not translated in English, but it is what you could expect when visiting a non-English speaking country. It is part of the experience when visiting a foreign country.
3. There are a few breweries near the museum you can visit after, especially the traditional Queirolo Tabern, which has traditional food and drinks.

Plaza de la Bandera: This plaza is dedicated to the national symbols of Peru. Here, you can learn about the history of the Peruvian flag, designed by José de San Martín, read excerpts from the national anthem, and find information about the Peruvian coat of arms. A special celebration takes place here every June 7th for Flag Day.

For all Peruvians it is a special place, in addition, June 7 is the day of the Peruvian Flag, and a Military Parade is held.

This corner of the Lima district of Chorrillos is an almost hidden place in this part of the Peruvian capital. When the beautiful Pedro de Osma avenue takes us to the district boundary between Barranco and Chorrillos, to the right are the streets that access this sector that houses beautiful houses, some from the beginning of the 20th century, including the summer house of former president Billingurst. It is a completely residential area so you will not find anywhere to eat. Ideal for walking and cycling. The view towards the sea is beautiful, you can see, among others, Pescadores beach and Morro Solar. Its approximately 500 meters of route culminate in the old "Chalet" school of the religious of the Sacred Heart.

In Comas, the community's cultural advancement is no longer surprising. The development of its youth and the legacy of its elders have allowed many citizens to showcase their talents and elevate the neighborhood. Among them, there are many notable figures in various circles, whether in sports, music, art, or science. They are making their names nationally and internationally, which fills this thriving district with pride. ..
There would not be enough space to name each of them. Just for example, in sports, there is the volleyball team, Deportivo Geminis, which has participated heavily in the Peruvian championship. In soccer, the "oreja" Flores from the Collique neighborhood stands out, as does the fullback from U Cabanillas...

I've been calling the Chorrillos Municipal central office and annexes for weeks, and THEY'RE NOT ANSWERING, not even via social media! They don't have the address on their Facebook page, but their Instagram page lists it as central (Defensores del Morro 550). I had to go to this location in person only to be told that the procedure I wanted to complete is done at the La Curva location (Huaylas/Defensores del Morro 2765). It's a waste of time and disrespectful to the residents and taxpayers of the district, many of them elderly who have trouble getting around. Even worse, I'm asking for a question that could have been EASILY resolved over the phone. It's the last straw that there's NO means of communication with the Municipality because the ones they have are just for show and they don't answer. Please answer your phones, use your social media accounts, and at least update your address!

Gentlemen, between Julio Calero and Haiti Streets, there is a house that has been abandoned for many years. The bush has grown so large that it only serves as a hiding place and is increasingly used for stealing.
In other years, requests have been made to cut it down, and they have done so.
Please consider this request.

Attention all citizens of Chorrillos and beyond! Zero stars for the Municipality and its shameful team. My mother dedicated 35 years of her life serving the community, earning everyone's respect for her tireless work helping hundreds of people. And what did she receive in return? Total contempt.

Unfortunately, the administration of Mr. Pablo Gutierrez Weselby and Mr. Agusto Miyashiro was marked by ignorance and flagrant violation of laws and collective bargaining agreements. Where have the raises and bonuses that pensioners are legally entitled to? They weren't given to them, and to top it all off, Mr. Gutierrez had the audacity to publicly display the list of pensioners with their names and salaries on the wall of the Huaylas office. What happened to human rights and privacy?

Recently, I had the misfortune of going to the Municipality to request my father's widow's pension after my mother's death. What an ordeal! The people at the counter seem to be in another world. Almost a month and no sign of progress. They don't allow access to human resources and give you an extension number that never answers. You leave messages and no one bothers to return the call.

It's shocking to see how Peru hasn't progressed since I left in 1999. Of course, institutions like the Municipality of Chorrillos are plagued by incompetence and lack of motivation. But remember, one day those same individuals will be elderly, and life will take its toll on them for the damage they have inflicted on others.

It's time to wake up and demand real change in our institutions. We cannot allow corruption, violence, and chaos to continue to dominate our beloved Peru. Let's demand a better future for all! 🇵🇪 #PeruWakeUp #ChorrillosInCrisis

By far the worst of the municipalities, its staff is highly incompetent. Phone calls can keep you on hold for up to an hour, only to be hung up on without ever answering. They force you to expose yourself to procedures that should be virtual, demanding things that are above the Administrative Simplification Law. The worst service of all.

Inefficient. Bureaucratic. The land registration process takes more than 15 days; in others, it only takes 15 minutes. This one isn't interconnected to anything. You only pay by card for less than S/. 50 soles. No preferential service. No waiting tables. Being here is like stepping back in time to the 1980s.

ACULL is a non-profit institution that brings together children and residents of Llamapsillo, Chongos Alto, Huancayo, Peru, in the capital city of Lima. It promotes culture and sports, uniting families who proudly display their surnames and, with them, their customs and traditions, preserving their cultural identity.
The Acull anthem, a poetic composition that describes the institutional sentiment and emotion, is thanks to Isaac Moreno, and the musical arrangements, the solemn tone that resonates in the conscience and heart of each of its members, are thanks to Santiago Moreno, both brothers, honorary members of Acull.
The Acull coat of arms, a symbol that represents us, features the mythical animal that identifies our origins, the llama, as well as the book and the ball, which symbolize study and sports. Its golden hue symbolizes abundance, prosperity, and well-being, and the black color of professionalism and seriousness, an improved design by Yen Yarin.
An institution that brings together hardworking, determined, entrepreneurial, and progressive people who proudly practice their ancestral Inca traditions such as Ayni and Minka.
